I decided to take my parents to have Korean food cuz they have never had it before (except on Korean Air, which you all know, it's bad). And not sure if my parents will want to go to Tofu Hut (the place I usually go), I researched about Korean places on Yelp, I found Soyo :) 

Even though this place is all the way across town, I'm glad I took the advice and came here. The service was good, one of the girls was really nice and always have a smile on her face. We ordered the bibimbap, marinated pork, deep fried chicken, and tofu hot pot. I liked all of them and they all tasted delicious :) I love how the foods are all sizziling when they come to the table. Even my dad, who is a picky eater, liked the food too, so this place certainly deserve a 5 star, it's hard to find a place that he likes :p

I also like the decoration of this place and will definitely be back for dinner or late night snack :) Good that this place is not right next to my house, or I will be eating out too often :p

spicy tofu seafood soup!
oh happy day, a korean joint in my neighborhood.  

it's like walking into a cozy little restaraunt in a young hip Korea.  
star 1 for the simple decor and mini video games [street fighter..& I forget the other] a giant chalkboard wall.... 

star 2 for the manga you can pulloff the shelves and read if your sitting in a booth.. 

star 3 for a very cool and welcoming waiter, and a good menu with lots of stuff to choose from.

star 4 for the yummy tasting and affordable food

they start u off with a big container of iced barley tea... [yum] I love tea, And their tea was especially good paired with the food.  

came for lunch and was very happy with the prices and selection.  we were starving so we decided we'd stay safe and order what we always ordered:

shortribs
kim chee fried rice
spicy seafood tofu soup..

with your meal your given a bunch of sides: kim chee, kim chee radishes, cold noodles, green beans, and peppers..
[very typical of Korean restaurants]  

my favorite dish was definitely the tofu seafood soup. regular spice was just enough spice.. the soup was sooo good.   

-short ribs had just a
little to much fat, but my husband liked
it very much.  

-kim chee fried rice was very good.   it was sticky and not to moist.  I hate moist watery rice! especially fried rice.   

all in all I loved the coziness.. 
-very well kept and clean
-our waiter was kind and courteous and checked on us often.. 
-we were filled up and even had left overs.

we left satisfied and didn't have that feeling that we were robbed.
will definitely come here again!

OMFG!!! this place is amazing! my advice for you is to get their spicy pork ribs - TOTAL GAME CHANGER!! make a reservation just to be on the safe side. I've never had Korean food other than Korean bbq, oh boy have I been missing out. I definitely recommend this place to anyone and everyone.
Service was good. Food was ok. How ever i would recommend not playing music that has curse words in it while kids r present

I love this place, I go here all the time with my friends! The atmosphere is super friendly and the music fits in nicely. I also like the bonchon and the variety they give. 

Now as for the actual entrees, I found most of them spicy, but then again I have a hard time with spices. My friends, on the other hand, loved it. We had military soup, omelette rice, rice cake, cheese chicken, and korean ribs. The barely tea definitely helped me survive all the spice.

I wish I could give zero star. 
We had 7 adults and 1 child in our group. They told us that they didn't have a big enough table for us to sit together now so if we want we can wait for 30-40 min or sit at separate tables. Then we sat down at two tables. During the meal, the service was beyond horrible. The food was average.

When we asked for the check, there was a 20% tip added onto our bill. They explained the charge was for large group more than 6 people. Well, we didn't seat together so we asked to have separate check for each table. Then they still charged the 20% tip on each check. We asked to take the tip off of the bill since we only have 4 people each table and we'd like to decide on the amount of tips. They tried to argue that we had 8 people in our group no matter what. In the end, they reprinted the checks again. This time, we were charged $3 for the appetizer dishes on one of the bills because accordingly what we ordered was not supposed to have complementary appetizers. Excuse me!? First of all, if that was the case, we never asked for the appetizers. They were served with our dishes. Second, it's not stated on the menu and we were not warned.

We asked to speak with the owner because the charges were just unreasonable and the reasons they gave were ridiculous. They told us that the owner was not there and refused to revise the bills again. In the end, we didn't have the time to sit there and wait for a police to come in. We still paid for the meal with no tip.

We understand that the waitresses were really busy and didn't have a chance to give better service. We originally wanted to give 10% tip but it turned out to be such a joke.

We will never come again.

I'd say 5 stars for a Korean resto in Vegas. But if compared to Korean resto in Cali and NYC, I'd say this is 3.5-4 stars. 

The service is awesome. There's always a server checking in on us. I think the manager even dropped by our table. 

SIDE DISHES - I like the beef steak and the macaroni salad. They also have kimchi. 

BULGOGI - Ask for it in BBQ style. I guess bulgogi in Vegas means it has broth or something. I'm used to BBQ style. It's not the best, but it's good enough to fill my cravings for Bulgogi. 

SUL LUNG TANG (oxtail soup) - It was pretty good. Just make sure you season it with salt and spices they bring your table. We only figured out until later that they want us to season it ourselves. After my boyfriend seasoned it, it was pretty good. 

DOLSOT BIBIMBAP - I like this one. Pretty good. 

LYCHEE SOJU - I only realized we can't take it home so my boyfriend and I had to finish it. Soju always has a sneak effect on me... The server said lychee is the most popular flavor for their soju. 

I'd say, don't go looking for Korean food in Chinatown. Go here instead!!!

For my first Korean dining experience, I enjoyed everything about it. I like the quaint, k-pop vibe and ambiance. Someone told me this place is a very modern, young, hip kind of Korean joint, compared to other traditional spots on Spring Mountain.  Being that I enjoy all things modern, i loved this place.

The wait staff are kind. The little plates that come out first are filled with lots of flavor. Never knew i liked kimchi til this done-in experience. The cost for items are reasonable too considering the portions.

I'm a Korean who has been to a lot of Korean restaurants in town. This place has a great atmosphere, very friendly and courteous staff(which you don't see too much of anymore), and the food... absolutely delicious!! I just couldn't get enough! I ate so much I could barely move. My mom has a little bit of competition ( sorry mom).  And the prices here are very reasonable compared to other Korean restaurants that charge you an arm and a leg. This place will definitely be our go to spot for Korean food.

Yook-gae-jang..

Thats all you need to order here.  A spicy beef and vegetable korean soup.. the flavors were on point and the side dishes were almost as good.

We got lucky as only 2 tables were seated and got our orders in before the place filled up quuckly.  This is obviously a go to place for the locals.

This place deserves a solid 3 stars. I have been here many times and tried a variety of things. Everything I have tried here is just subpar and a poor excuse for korean food.  But it might just be my spoiled taste buds from living in cali.

I came here with my in laws after a long day of driving to and from the Grand Canyon. We were in serious need of some good food by the time we got back to Las Vegas and we wanted to get our korean food on. 

We came before it turned into a "bar" so I don't really know how the "bar scene" is here. We ordered soondubu and kam ja tang. The food itself was ok. Not really anything that stood out. The soondubu's broth was good but was there wasn't much seafood in it at all. I didn't get to tasted the kam ja tang because I filled up on the soon dubu but my husband and his parents said it was ok.

All in all, it was an ok place. But nothing that I would rave about. Service was good. No major problems, but I would probably try something else when we crave korean food around vegas.
My "go to" Korean BBQ place in the neighborhood! Great food! And, they stay open late!

I actually like it here. Very energetic environment. Lots of good drinks. 
I've had better Korean food elsewhere but it's good enough to have a good time with friends, and I think that's the whole idea behind this joint. 
Service was excellent. Cracks me up when the staff is trying to figure out whether to speak to me in Korean or not, but nevertheless, they were cool.

Maybe because I just came back from Seoul, Korea about two months ago or I used to live in New Jersey, one of largest Korea town in US for more than 10 yrs, so I just cannot say the taste of the plates that I ordered were fantastic. Average.
However, I was happy to see many Americans were in the restaurant because as you probably all know, most of Korean restaurants stand for just Korean, which very awkward to see here in US. (Awesome atmosphere, I felt comfortable to bring my American and Chinese friends.)
The price and the parking spaces were good.
I will bring my friends again next time.

Great little Korean barstaurant! Cute atmosphere, nice helpful staff, & delicious food. Tried the handmade flat dumplings, steamed pork belly with cabbage & spicy radish appetizer, & cold noodle with kimchi & cucumber in a spicy sauce. Everything had so much flavor! The flat dumplings were perfectly crispy, the pork belly app was large & very tasty- the pork belly was steamed just right, & the spicy cold noodle dish was amazing.

The barley tea in tin cups upon sitting was a nice touch. Our server was very helpful with her recommendations and helping guide us through the menu.

We will definitely be back!

This is my go-to neighborhood korean restaurant. Love that they are always open late and never too crowded. We usually order the marinated short ribs or gaal-bi, and korean fried chicken which are musts. Stone pot bi bim bap is also very good, as well as their fried mackerel. They offer very few sides, but you can ask for more of something if you like it.

The service and food here is consistently exceptional.  I haven't tried anything because I am in love with the spicy tofu and seafood soup.  On a cold day this soup not only fills you up but also give you that nice tingling warm feeling.  It's a cute and clean little restaurant and they do decorate according to the holidays and season.  The little dish is free of charge and comes along with your meal.  You will not leave this place hungry.  

This place us great for a late night snack and they play some fantastic house and trance music here, make me wanna dance.

If you love Korean BBQ, come try this place.  Hip... fun and good food.  Whenever we're in town, we will try to come dine here.  Last visit was on 03/21 and the food still so delicious.  Our favorite is the thick seafood pancake, the seafood casserole, fried chicken and bulgogi.  Good service and recommend calling ahead to reserve a table.  It gets pretty busy here!

Soyo is my favorite Korean restaurant! Whenever I'm craving Korean food, I go here to fulfill my cravings! Everything here is really good, and my favorite foods here are the corn cheese and casserole. I would definitely recommend this restaurant for any occasion!

Service: Awesome
Parking: I can see how it may fill up on weekends, but we lucked out and parked right outside!
Food: THE KIMCHI PANCAKE IS THE BEST. Family also ordered kimchi jjigae, bi bim bap/naengmyun, spicy pork (hella awesome too!), tonkatsu (with cheese), and mandoo. Food was all excellent, and we ate family style...everyone was stuffed! Great place and would recommend and come again!

If you're hungry in the middle of the night then this is the place to go! It's open late night and has great Korean food. I love their variety of soups they have and different tapas. I love their spicy need soup and I love their soon tofu. Their spice levels perfectly spicy where you can actually feel DA HEAT. They also have this deal when you spend $40 you can spin for free food or discounts! So when I spun the wheel I won a free soju bottle!

Very good soju and the atmosphere was wonderful!Loved the Banchan and everything else! 

**7/30/14- still as awesome as ever. I love the grilled Mackerel.

I've been here three times and each time it just gets better. The food is very good and they have the full range of Korean food on their menu so you can try something unique and exciting every time you come.

Very good Korean food. We had beef bulgogi and spicy pork ribs. It was quite spicy so be ready for that. Although not near as hot as some thai food I've had, it doesn't make me sweat.  Only thing I could complain about is not as many side dishes as most places but they were very good. Overall highly recommended a lot of authentic dishes that are hard to find.

The food here is delicious! They only get three stars; however, as the wait time is FOREVER. It doesn't matter when we go. We went in one night on a Friday night and waited for over an hour for our food. No one came to our table to check on us, refill our drinks, or offer us an explanation as to why it was taking so long. My fiancé ended up walking up to our server and asked what the status of our order was. He was confused and asked "What did you order again?" We ended up leaving as they clearly never put the order in. Since we've been here before and waited long for our food, we weren't willing to continue sitting there waiting after that type of service.

Any place called a barstaurant definitely has my attention. An establishment that fully promotes both their alcohol and food deserves attention. 

Prices for this place are pretty decent, especially for the amount of food that you get. I usually opt for AYCE Korean restaurants, as I usually like to stuff my face with as much food as possible. But on the weird nights, where I don't want to overdo it, I go to Soyo. 

Service is great. They're fast and friendly, and always make sure your tea/water is filled. 

Now for the part I enjoy the most, alcohol !! They have a few varieties of beer. But, the real reason I go there is for the Soju [Korean alochol]. They have about 8 or 9 different flavors, if I remember correctly. It's only 12 dollars for a bottle. My favorite flavor would definitely have to be a mixture of the yogurt and the lychee. With a bottle of yogurt lychee soju and some Korean food, your night is bound to go well.

Second time here. First time was a great experience, the waiter was extremely helpful and polite since we've never been here. This brought us back here for this second time. It was not the same case.

The female waitress rushed our order without asking if we needed any advice or help, when I said I would like to order the tofu tapas. She blurted if I wanted the entree or the tapas without explaining the differences and when I asked what's the difference she only said one is the tapas and one is the entree. When the tofu arrived, I asked if we get rice with the dishes and she said no. I stated we had them last time and she said not with this dish, okay that's fine, we ordered 2 bowls of rice. When the rest of the food came out(Korean pork belly with house salad), she didn't bring the side dishes like we had last time, I waved her down and asked if we get them. She said not with these dishes, okay I assumed the pork belly was a entree considering it was 13$ and on the front of the menu close to where the entrees were and it didn't distinguish above what it fell under. She said it would be extra for the side dishes and didn't explain for which ones or anything. I asked for another menu because if I would've known any of this information before, I would've ordered an entree. 

Eating Korean food entails the side dishes such as kimchi, pickled cucumbers, beans and whatever else comes with. 

She never came back to ask if I wanted to order another dish then I saw her leaving the restaurant in a rush, get in her car and drive away. 

What sort of service is this? I came back because I had a great experience the first time and she thoroughly ruined it with her terrible lack of customer service and attitude. 

The food is was still good, but with this sort of service. Who cares? That's the only reason for the 2nd star given. 

I might come back only because of the food.

I miss Vegas!! Not for it's clubs and nightlife on The Strip, but because of SOYO!  I'm usually not a fan of soju, not even yogurt soju.  Something about being able to still taste the alcohol even though it's mixed in well... but I don't know what Soyo does to theirs that it was addicting! 

Thank goodness my ex-housemate brought me out to a local place. I loved it!  They have booths and regular tables, but choose the booth. It's a really comfy and cozy.  We sat there, drank, gossiped, and ate for almost 3 hours? The employees were so kind and kept refilling out bottles up with more yogurt soju.  Big tip for them! They even shared their secret to making yogurt soju at home (we didn't know how much to add of the three ingredients!)

Bottle after bottle, it was delicious!  Forget about XS, Tao, and Haze. I'm going to Soyo next time I'm back in Vegas :)

Cool and kinda trendy place for good Korean food late into the night 

Ambiance
Cool and kinda trendy haphazard quasi disheveled interior. A few booths along the side with benches and tables in the center. Try for a booth as the benches have no back support so can get uncomfortable. They're open late into the night. When we were there they had pretty loud Korean rap laced with profanities playing continuously. That's ok for a song or two, but how about some Girls Generation or other K-pop now and then?

Service
Friendly and attentive even though the servers all seemed young. They were always refilling the tea and offered to add more broth to the soup. 

Food
Delicious garlic chicken wings which were tender and tasty and crispy on the outside. Awesome!  Great spicy soup also which was flavorful and tasted great. Tons of side dishes which you can have more of too for no extra charge. Great kimchi!!  

Mojo
This is a simple sorta trendy place that has great food and is open late for that midnight kimchi kraving!!

They did not skimp on the alcohol content in my soju!

I actually had to ask them to add more soda for me.

I love the atmosphere here.  It's off the strip (Rainbow, south of the 215) and the music is bumping.  It's so cute on the inside!

My husband likes the katsu and the short ribs look really good.  The soup and plain pancakes are just ok.

I just really enjoy this cool hang out spot with the option to eat, drink, and be merry...without costing the commercial cost and feel of the Las Vegas Strip.  

Love this BARstaurant!

I have been here on multiple occasions for lunch, dinner, or even late night drinks, but I wanted to give them a good review for their service on 01/01/2018.

I was having a potluck dinner but was too lazy to cook, because we had been out the night before for NYE. My friend called in an order for kimchi jji gae (6 to be exact) around 12noon. They told us it would be ready in about 30 mins. When we arrived, the food was ready and neatly packed in a box. The gentleman insisted that he carried the box to my car. When we got home, we saw that each soup order came with rice and korean sides (kimchee, sweet black beans, and pickled raddish) SCORE! Everything was nicely packed and easy to carry. 

The soup was delicious and the sides paired well.
The food was a hit at the party. Food portion was generous as well. Thanks Soyo!!
The blood sausage was great but the service wasn't that great because the server didn't understand us and guessed on what we may like

Soyo has done for Korean food what Raku did to revolutionize Japanese food in Las Vegas. Soyo is (at least of 3/4/2011) the new and trendy hidden jewel that Raku used to be for adventurous foodies in Las Vegas. Unlike Japanese cuisine which is often praised on its minimalist perfection, Korean cuisine is the celebration of the bold, spicy, and complex flavors that are relatively still new to the United States.

Just like Italian food utilizes a lot of parsley, or like how a lot of Thai or Mexican food utilizes cilantro, Korean spices mainly consist of green onions, garlic, and chili powder/paste and can be a bit spicy. 

The type of Korean food served at Soyo is much like an izakaya or tappas restaurant where you order a collection of bar food to accompany your alcoholic beverage of choice.

Besides the standard "banchan" or mini side dishes that accompanies every Korean meal, you should order about one entrée per every two people in your party (although this depends on the type of entrée you get) as Korean dinning is communal (think family style) and food is shared, not individually served. 

The holy grail of Soyo is the "Bu-dae Jjigae." A Jjigae is what Koreans would call or compare most closely with a western stew. During the Korean War when American lead UN troops were fighting on the Korean peninsula, they brought with them sausages and spam. The Koreans took this and combined it with their national stew, the "kimchi jjigae," to create the ultimate poor mans comfort food. 

The Bu-dae Jjigae is spicy and big enough to feed about three to four people here, so this isn't something you'd tackle on by yourself unless you are extremely brave or foolish of heart.

The beverage of choice here is "makgeolli" which is a type of traditional Korean milky rice wine. The makgeolli is often served in a large urn with a ladle and you are supposed to spoon the beverage out into the bowl like cups provided for you. For those who think the makgeolli is too thick, a lot of young Koreans have been known to mix the drink with 7up or sprite and sip it as a cocktail.

The food isn't reflective of traditional or authentic Korean cuisine, but Soyo does a wonderful job in representing Korean bar food culture. Everyone should try this place out.

The first thing that impressed me was that Soyo isn't an AYCE place.  Not that AYCE places are bad!  I've just visited places that boast AYCE and the quality just falls under my (snobby) standards.  Soyo is super cute on the inside, with twinkling lights, a "Price is Right" style spinning wheel, and signs in Hangul (and we all know that printed Hangul is super cute, what with all the "sticks and circles" --hubby's words -- in that particular written language!). 

Our party of 4 snagged a booth and ordered a variety of delights: bibimbap, fried chicken, chapchae, etc.  Barley tea was flowing liberally, the banchan was plentiful and tasty, and hubby got his fill of kimchi to last for the next few weeks.  Everything was delicious and the sweet, if slightly clueless server, was more than happy to bring us drink refills and napkins (after reminding him several times).  It was nice not to have our clothes saturated with bbq smoke after our meal, something that is a given at AYCE bbq places I've patronized.  

I will definitely come here again to eat and to spin that wheel!

I actually used to really like this place and maybe this occurance was a one off with a bad seed (employee) but needless to say one bad experience can create a bad taste in your mouth for a very long time. 

I came here for lunch and let me start by saying NOBODY was there yet. We ordered our food AT the same time but it came out separately. About 5 min passed between the first and second dish then about 10 min later we wondered where our 3rd dish was. Let me say the fact that nobody was around for 10 minutes isn't probably the best as far as customer service and/or possible revenue lossage for the risk of someone just walking out. So we finally find someone and we ask about our food, he said oh ya let me go check on it for you. He came back and asked us again what we were missing (so did he totally not hear us 2 min before)....we told him and then he said oh you didnt order that. We stare blankly at him and said yes we did, he continued to argue with us and even more INSULT us by pulling out his notepad and asked "if we wanted to see his paper". We stopped him right there and said no!  Are you SERIOUS?!? Customer service!!! 

The food isn't horrible but with this incredibly insulting experience, I am pretty sure we will drive that extra 10 min to another Korean spot.

The atmosphere at Soyo is very upbeat.  I have tried many items on the menu, but I have only one favourite: Aal Baap.  Although the menu seems to offer tons of things, most of the dishes are not amazing.  The bibimbap and soon tofu are also good.

The K-Pop music is played quite loudly, and the restaurant itself is very loud.  If you are seeking a more quiet atmosphere, request a booth, because the booths are partly closed off.  It's often crowded at night, especially Saturdays.  There are some people in the staff that are quite courteous and helpful, but there are a few workers that are inefficient and somewhat rude.  The food at Soyo is pretty good, but the atmosphere is loud and some of the staff's behaviour upsetting.

Looking for a late night place to eat (late night being after 10pm by Summerlin standards), we drove out here.  It's kind of hard to see from the blazing lights of Oyshi Sushi but it's just off to the left of Oyshi.  This also coincided with Chris M.'s UYE, which was perfect.

Hite beer on tap (and in the bottle).  Morimoto Soba Ale on tap.  Soju. Tiny little video game machines.  That would be enough for me.

But the food is great, too! Our party of four shared a bunch of different dishes including spicy chicken with mozzarella, spicy pork belly and bean sprouts, mandu dumplings, kimchi and tofu soup, and a seafood scallion pancake.  Plus a few other dishes I did not try (so much food) and all the traditional Korean sides. The food portions are generally huge so plan accordingly.  Also, don't be afraid to mix and match.  Chris discovered that the sauce for the spicy chicken went great with the dumplings.  Who knew?

The complimentary iced barley tea was delicious and I like the tin bowl service.  But I'm pretty sure it's caffeinated so I only had a bit.

The spicy pork belly and bean sprouts came on it own portable stove, which was pretty large and unwieldy.  We ate pretty fast and didn't turn it on (were we supposed to?) so I wasn't quite sure the purpose of this as it took up valuable space on an already crowded table. 

At the end of your meal, its probably best to just approach the servers and ask for the check.  Thankfully Chris knew this or we would have been sitting for much longer wondering what was up.  Our bill was  very reasonable for all the food and alcohol my husband and I had.  Didn't even make it to the $75 mark so we could spin the wheel.  :)

Definitely a fan and will definitely be back.

Favorite dishes are the dumplings, the marbled beef salad, and katsu. Every dish is fabulous. Service is great. Quick. Consistent. Occasionally the Korean pop music is a bit much... But food is worth it.
Whenever I'm craving Korean food I always know soyo's is SOLID! Love the kalbi, sundobu & seafood casserole with ramen!!!!

Been back quite a few times since my last review. Food is still just as good and I've discovered many new and yummy items on the menu. ALBAP! Mmm... Now that they've added BBQ this place is now the perfect Korean joint in my book. Yay Kalbi! Service is still great - attentive, but non-intrusive. Definitely give this place a try if you haven't yet.

I went here with a large group to eat and drink and I was very impressed with the overall quality of the Korean food. Being from LA, I was a bit hesitant, but the reviews are correct. You can get some really good korean bar food and be able to hang out and drink the night away at this place. It's hard to find these types of places anywhere else but in LA Ktown, but this one in the Southwest of Las Vegas definitely reminds me of home. I definitely have to go back again with friends, as it is a place to hang out for a good few hours, eating and drinking. I've tried the kimchee fried rice, the spicy wings, and the pork belly and squid platter (see pictures). Everything was really good and always goes well with some soju and beer. Definitely need to make my way back over there soon.

Ordered Dol Sot Bi Bim Baap, and there was hardLy any taste to it. I mixed it up right away with the chiLi paste so I didn't reaLLy see if there was ground beef. But by the Look/taste of it, I don't think they put any. If there was then I can teLL u how smaLL and tasteLess those pieces are! LOL

Came here for dinner last night with Ardie Y and my favorite Korean, Stephanie K. It was my 1st time at Soyo and I can already say I'm a fan and will be back. I loved the decor and atmosphere/vibe of the place which seemed really different for a small Korean restaurant. I also liked that they have both indoor and outdoor seating.

I don't know much about Korean food but a lot of things on the menu sounded good so I had trouble deciding on what to get. I eventually went with the bibimbap, which was certainly interesting...It's not that I didn't like it, I just don't think it's for me. Eating a mashed up bowl of various items makes it hard to discern and taste exactly what I'm eating and it really didn't taste like anything to me except hot sauce. Aside from that, their food presentation is really nice and no matter what you order, everything looked pretty damn good when looking around. I also tried the kimchi fried rice, which was extremely greasy but oh so delicious, and some Korean dumplings (no idea what they're called) that were pretty tasty.

Service was excellent, especially for an Asian restaurant since I'm usually not expecting any service at all. We were constantly checked on and new carafes of tea were being brought over before we could finish ours. I already have a list of things I want to try next time around, be back soon Soyo!

We had a party of 12.  Great service. Celebrating my boyfriends birthday. I ordered marbled beef tastes great with the salt pepper sesame oil, Kalbi, and peach Soju is my favorite.  They gave my man a large intense birthday shot of some heavy liquor.  The server also came out with a plastic bag (just in case.) I thought that was clever and different.  I kept it by my side the rest of dinner. But he kept all his drinks and food down just fine.  Very convenient for large parties as you go to the cashier, let them know what you ordered, and pay.  It's fast and easy, ensures you don't get stuck with everyone's tax and tip.

This is the best Korean restaurant! Very very good Korean food! Fresh tofu soup, BBQ style bulgogi, fire chicken, and more~~~ We love to stop by whenever just to have a simple dinner or meeting with friends. Keep up the good work Soyo.

My friend and I went searching for a good Korean spot and this place came up during our search.  I can say that our Yelp search did not lead us wrong. I liked the decor of the restaurant, we sat in a booth and it was very comfortable. Here is rundown of what we tried.

Spicy soup with shredded beef - Very good, the broth was spicy but not overpowering. The noodles were similar to ramen and there was plenty of other goodies in the soup.

Kalbi Ribs - Some of the best I have had. The sauce was very good and the ribs were not fatty at all. The serving size was also large, which was a nice surprise.

Seafood Pancake - Not bad, probably would try other things on the menu before ordering this again. The pancake was ok, it was huge and served on a cast iron pan so it stayed warm. However, the I thought the flavor was a little bland even with the sauce that is served on the side.
Food is really tasty. The best jab che I have ever tasted. The price is very reasonable too. Staff is nice and patient with demanding customers like our group

Wow. What an awesome Korean restaurant. 
Everything was literally so good. I tried all my friends food lol and everything was so good. 
So I got the bip bim bob. (I don't how to spell it) 
Didn't really have much of a flavor but I think that's the way it's supposed to be. I guess on the healthier side. 
The Kim chi fried rice was also good because it had A LOT of flavors. Just hits you in the face with flavors. 
We also got this pork belly thing with the salad thing which was also really really good. 
My friend for the bean sprouts dish thing with octopus in it, it was $25 but it was enough to share with the whole table. 
They also serve you with ice tea that taste like rice, which is my fav drink. 
I'm definitely coming back to this place and also recommend it to anyone who wants really good Korean good that's not kbbq lol

I'll give two stars since the food is so good. I've been here twice before and the service was good, but nothing extraordinary. 

Today's service was bad because of our rude and incompetent waitress. My friend asked for pork instead of ground beef for her bibimbap, and the waitress said no right away. Then, we asked if we can have just the kimchi and fish cakes for our banchan. The waitress rudely interrupted my friend and was like, "Yeah, the side dishes come with your meal. We have fish cakes." WTF?!

She only checked up on us once and my friend had to go up to her in order to get the check. She was catering to everyone else (Korean customers) many times; I believe we were looked down upon because we're not Korean. I'll probably be back again for my bibimbap, but hopefully she won't be my waitress next time.

this is as close as it gets to having similar type of food in korea. the only better thing soyo has is that its way cleaner and doesnt have completely trashed people flopping around on the walls and floor like a similar restaurant in the college districts would.

the grilled mackerel is usually cooked just right. few times was eh. but not many places in town give you a whole mackerel for that price. they change up the side dishes often and they taste good. a lot of korean restaurants in vegas suck because their side dishes arent that good. even my parents enjoy eating here.

the employees are always courteous and cute (only the girls are cute). 

if youre into cocktail soju they have a few different flavors. but i hate soju, so i dont get any of them. i usually drink purple haze.

i tolerate the k-pop...

Came here the other night with some friends. We chose to have dinner here because they used to have the morimoto soba ale. To our surprise, they no longer have this beer... Even bottled :( such a shame but oh well! I still enjoy going here because of the late hours, cool vibe, great food and decent prices.

Soyo is that little gem that you find during your late night Asian cravings and don't want to drive all the way to Chinatown. You definitely have to come here with hungry friends so you can share multiple dishes.  One of my favorites is the C1 casserole with all sorts seafood. Its this huge pot they bring to your table with a burner that just simmers on the side of the table. They use to refill the broth for free but now they charge $2 I think which is still not bad. All the basic Korean bbq basics are good and they cook it for you. The chicken wings are good as well. Just get a pitcher of beer and some Soju and you are all set! They are open till 3 am and always busy but getting a seat is always fast. It's a little pricey but definitely worth it and not so bad if you share with friends.

Been here many times now and it always reminds me of Korea. The decor, staff and ambience is very indicative of "the land of the morning calm."

The food is moderately priced and the lychee soju is the go-to cocktail. Be careful though, its intoxicating allure can creep up on you without realizing it.

No need for further detail... go check this place out!
I have been looking for Gam Jaa Taang since I left Korea. I found it... Hell Yeah!!! It is a cure all soup.

I really like the food here. My boyfriend and I frequent this place. We always get the same thing but its because it's so good. We always get the shin ramen, and we don't care if its instant. It has a nice spice to it and they include an egg with, and anyone who is a ramen lover knows egg is a must! We also always get the grilled pork belly with chive salad. The pork is nicely cooked and they top it with roasted garlic yum! They are pretty generous with those sides that are complimentary. Ive tried lots of other things which are tasty as well but I just love their pork belly.

Soyo serves up some of the better Korean food in the area.  They are good with what they do and that's creating excellent higher than average quality Korean food in a good bar restaurant environment. They have your usual Korean dishes with some being misses for me. Highly recommend their delicious spicy wings my fave, spicy enough to make me sweat a little, crispy enough to my liking borderline burnt/extra crispy. I didn't like the very spicy chicken with cheese melted on, it wasn't spicy at all and not so great even if it wasn't spicy, they might have messed up the order. The bibimbap was ok but didn't stand out. The Kalbi was good and so were they're soups. Prices are higher than I'd expected.

When you come in you'll notice that they aren't huge so you might expect to wait on busy nights/days.  They have booths built like a cubby hole or a little home and there's some patio space.

They are open pretty late into the AMs which is awesome and perfectly located for the SW people.  There are still people eating late so you don't have worry about eating alone or holding up the kitchen.
Sweet and Spicy pork was good but overall food was average (Korean beef was like what I have had so many times before and the squid was over-cooked too chewy)... Good music and atmosphere though!

I love Soyo! Every time I come to visit Las Vegas to visit my boyfriend, we always make it a point to come here because it is so good. We usually get the Bulgogi, Kimchi Fried Rice, and the Cheese Corn, etc. Everything is just really good here. The portions are a great size, the workers are very nice. They have nice new outside eating area too. Good vibes

This place is really cool to go to the ambience is decorated like a Korean hang out you can get lost by looking around with all the decorations the food is amazing there are multiple decisions that you can go super wild or super tame just depends on how your taste buds are working that day
The place was close by my house so My friends and I came here for dinner. I like the service and the food. Especially i get free ice cream at the end

Yelp 2017 100 Challenge:
2017 Review 40/100

Rating: 4.5

This Korean "barstaurant" provides good Korean food at a very Korea like atmosphere. For Koreans, it's a good reminder of the Korean style of an indoor but "outdoor imitating" pocha. For non Koreans, it's a great atmosphere to experience Korean culture! I would definitely return again!

My husband and I came here because we were starving at about 12:30am and yelp said they were open. We were greeted when we walked in and we're given a private feeling booth. There are things written all over the walls and the music was bumping. Definitely an awesome late night hole in the wall feel! 

Now, I haven't had Korean food since I studied abroad in China (weird I know) and my husband had never tried Korean food. The server was so incredibly friendly and helpful with all of our stupid questions. He told us all his favorite things and the most popular items! I got his #1 recommendation: the short rib (so mouthwatering), and then we ordered a variety of other things. My husband wanted hot noodles and the server made a recommendation that was spot on. All of the food was amazing and the portions are large!

I'll definitely be frequenting this spot more often! Not only is the ambiance fun but the food and service are outstanding!

Very cute and delicious place especially if you are looking to grab a late night bite. I have been here several times and have yet to have a bad experience. The iced barley tea has a wonderful toasty flavor and inspired me to purchase some for my home. It is especially nice in the hot summer. Although I do feel like I am drinking out of a dog bowl.

The fried dumplings come out nice and hot with a dipping sauce that complements their flavor. The Dolsot Bibimbap is great with the bowl that adds a nice crispiness to the rice. I am not a huge fan of the sweet chili rice cakes. They were a bit too sweet for my liking but the budae jjigae is delicious. 

When ever I go here I leave with leftovers. I recommend taking people you do not mind sharing with.

Just as a warning, you can ask them to make the spicy grilled chicken with mozzarella as spicy as they can and they do not hold back... I have a pretty good tolerance for spice and wow. My eyes were immediately watering with just one bite and it was one of those burns that just gets stronger. I am not the one who ordered it but the person who did saw it as a challenge and did complete the dish. However he did say it was the spiciest thing he has ever eaten.

We went here for lunch today.

When we walked in we sat at a table with two benches. The waitress suggested that we sit at a booth so we'd be more comfortable. We took her suggestion and moved to a booth by the wall. She asked if we'd been there before, and we told her it was our first time.

She was very nice and explained the menu and told us about the complimentary tea and sides.

I am not a big fan of tea, but it was pretty good. Kind of like a woodsy, green iced tea.

She then brought out the sides which consisted of seaweed salad,
green flower with sesame (I think that's what she called it, looked kinda like broccoli rabe), Cole slaw, marinated potatoes, kim chee, and marinated cabbage stems (I think that's what it was). My favorites were the potatoes and the cole slaw.

For our entrees we ordered the kimchee and pork soup and the kalbi beef ribs. The soup was hot, both spice and temperature-wise. In fact it was boiling when she brought it out. It was really good and a perfect antidote to my cold. The kalbi was also very good. It was well-marinated and had a nice char to it.

The waitress checked on us frequently to make sure everything was okay and see if we wanted any more of the sides. 

We definitely enjoyed our meal and will likely be back.

My boyfriend and I came here a little after they opened, so we received great service! I have a slight obsession with soon Dubu tofu soup ever since I had it in my hometown back in California. I've yet to find a place that is equivalent to the ones I've tried out there but this one comes close! There side dishes were appetizing and the best part is that you can get refills on your favorite ones! Aside from ordering my seafood tofu, we ordered the Kalbi ribs and the kimchi fried rice! All of which were tasty!

Can't wait to come back!

With the experience in traveling that I have- when we walked into the restaurant, I realized that it looked exactly how a cute little bar in Korea would look! So I immediately loved it! 

Food is great, decently portioned, & reasonably priced... We get the Galbi every time as one entree and then try a new dish. We share 2 entrees between myself, my husband, and my son. They bring as many side dishes as you like, which keeps me smiling! And they have different side dishes/kimchi each time I go...
 
5 out of the 6 times that we have gone ((in the past 3 weeks)), we have had great service- but that 1 unlucky day will not keep us from not coming back :)
Food is nice,the service is good,but the music is a little bit too loud .The hotpot must try.

The food is delicious and inexpensive. The music they play here is very up to date. The interior of the restaurant is super cute, it's like a hipster Korean restaurant. I loved the booths! And the customer service is great, our server Dennis was very attentive! Will definitely be back!

Soyo is a pretty decent korean restaurants in town. I really like their mini arcade machines as well near the entrance, it seriously reminds me of the last time i went to korea for a visit, it makes me really nostalgic. The interior is pretty nice, authentic korean feel, and even has outdoor seating. Now for the serious stuff, we ordered the cheese corn, kimchi fried rice, spicy sea food udon, spicy rice cake, and bulgogi. Their food is a little bit intense on the spicy scale and that is saying a lot considering I grew up on Korean food and have a pretty tolerance and love for spicy meals. Their bulgogi plate is hard to ever really mess up so I give it a so so rating and their spicy udon and rice cake was pretty good, it reminded me of home and not too chewy. Portions for their entrees are very good and pricing is pretty decent considering it fed 4 people.

I have to admit I'm kind of a Korean food newbe but I've been here twice (the only two times I've had Korean food) and the food here has been delicious both times. The staff is super engaging and friendly as well. I'll be back for sure

It's good place to try Korean dishes and alchol.
It's Bar and  Restaurant mixed theme.
Good service, nice food.

There's so much on the menu, I imagine you can find something for everybody! It's more fun to share family style so you can try more things. 

Corn Cheese $6: I love me some corn cheese! This is a good small plate/app to share. 

Cheese Baby Back Rib $17: Yum more cheese! The sauce is tasty as well. 

Gal Bi Sam Gyup Sal $16: The salad that came with this was a refreshing break from all the cheese. The pork belly with their sauce was also good. 

Yogurt Soju $12: This was delicious! Last time I also tried peach and lychee, but yogurt is my fav.

I was just saying I haven't been to this spot yet, however many of my friends have. Turns out some of the girls have decided to have some dinner and drinks the other night. I had plans for the night for LATER so I decided to join them. For some Soju! WELL obviously I can't be some place and NOT eat and the food looked so good and we WERE drinking so I HAD to eat. DUH. 
We had Bibimbap and some kind of hot pot casserole seafood thingy. It was a HUGE portion for the four of us girls and it was very seafoody, and delicious and spicy. Good stuff! I like this place and I will definitely be back!

Love the beef here, One of the best tofu soup in town, the side dishes are awesome, totally refillable, we love the peach flavor soju in here, personally I hate the taste of soju, but I drink a lot of peach flavor sunny in here. Come and try it, you won't regret.

Over rated! Customer was not good and food was just ok was not impressed! MamaOh and Doh food is better and customer service is great way better if you are looking for Korean food around this area FYI. Also I was getting grossed out Nat problems! Flying to our food and we was getting grossed out!

My family and I tried this place for the first time and we loved it!  The customer service was great!  The food was superb!  We tried their spicy chicken dish, kalbi ribs, and some type of beef dish and they were all tasty.  Their sides are home made, too, so that of course was good!  They are pretty affordable, too!  This is definitely the spot for late night dinner.

I wish yelp allowed half stars. I would give it a 3.5. Depending on what you order, some dishes are either a 3 or 4 for me. Most of them a 3. Service is hit or miss, depends how busy they are. However when I pick up food, it's always ready.

RE: Pick up orders. I wish they would give more rice for some of the soups/stews. I got sul lung tang (ox bones soup) to go and ended up making rice. I think double the rice would be sufficient.

RE: Appetizers & Main dishes. I wasn't a fan of their mandoo (dumplings), spicy, marinated chicken wings, haemul jun gol (seafood casserole), mussels soup, and kimchi chigae but I like their omelette rice and corn cheese. Their kimchi bokkumbap and soon tofu were alright. I forgot what else I ordered from here even though I've been here more than ten times.

RE: Banchan. Probably one of the better selections of side dishes that Korean restaurants in Vegas offer for the most part except their kimchi. It can be a hit or miss depending on what type they serve.

RE: Drinks. I like that they give you a complimentary plastic bottle of boricha (barley tea). They sell decent beers along with soju too. The manager gave me a carafe of complimentary yogurt (or was it lemon?) soju when they first opened so that's always welcomed!

Light, fluffy pillows of tofu soup!!!...Spicy, elastic buckwheat noodles!!!...Flavorful slices of marbled beef!!!...There are so many great things to enjoy at Soyo!

It took far too many years for me to include Korean food as one of the mainstays when eating out. I think it was because I was so dreadfully afraid of receiving a KOREAN KIMCHI SLAP...and if you're not familiar with that, you should google that now and rest assured that you are in no danger of such a horrible experience happening at Soyo. 

The bibimnaengmyeon is my favorite.  It is cold buckwheat noodles in a spicy sauce with some fresh root veggies for a little texture. It is a little on the spicy side, but an ancillary benefit is that it helps to clean you out the morning after. Another Soyo favorite is their Soondubu Jjigae (Spicy Tofu Soup). I don't mind tofu, but I rarely looked forward to ordering tofu until I came across this dish. Korean heat is one of my favorite styles for spicy foods.  This dish balances that heat, with rich and full flavors. A final go-to is Soyos Chaa Dol Baak E Boo Choo Moo Chim Salad. This dish is certainly light on the salad and plentiful with thin slices of marbled beef. What the salad brings is a nice bit of acid to cut the fattiness of the savory beef.

Soyo is a "Barstaurant" which, best as I can tell, means it's a restaurant that can at times have a fun, slightly lively, feeling going on when the Soju is flowing freely. Still the name is a bit vexing. In general, it is just a cool Korean restaurant...so stop by and check it out if you're looking for good Korean eats!

This is my first review here on yelp, so bear with me. Anyways, thanks to a buddy of mine (who is also a yelper) I have discovered a new outlook and love for Korean food. My past experiences consisted pretty much of Korean table BBQ (which is great!) and their instant noodles. That is pretty much all I knew until I went to the Soyo Korean Barstaurant. The variety of different types of Korean foods was amazing since I didn't know they existed. I mean I knew that there had to be more to Korean foods, but I just had the impression that they only specialized in BBQ. 

Some of the dishes that I tried were the "Odang" (fish cake soup) which was absolutely amazing! On my first sip of the broth it reminded me of the Japanese Miso soup, but just 20 times better and a lot richer in flavor. Another dish that I tried was the whole fried chicken with the salt/pepper and the sesame oil. The chicken was cooked just perfectly, so it wasn't too dry, moreover the skin was nice and crispy with lots of flavor. For those of you that prefer a heavier flavor you can use the salt/pepper combo or sesame seed oil which compliment the chicken perfectly. 

My personal favorite at Soyo is the Budae jjigae which is an Army based stew. To give you a a quick overview of what it is, it's basically a bunch of stuff tossed in a big pot of spicy soup. The "stuff" consists pretty much of korean instant noodles, spam, hot dogs, sausage, rice cakes, and kimchi. This may seem like an odd combination for a soup, but TRUST me, it's the perfect dish for those cold days. It's also a good alternative to the typical bar food that you may eat, and after having the Budae jjigae, I would choose it over the buffalo wings, french fries etc. any day of the week.

I have tried some other dishes as well, unfortunately I forget the names of them, but let me tell you that they all were delicious! It's not everyday that you can find a restaurant where you like everything that they serve.

Not only is the food absolutely amazing, but the staff is friendly as well and very attentive. They also serve a variety of different types of alcohol, and specialize in a variety flavors of soju. Prices are also very reasonable. Overall I give this place 4 stars as of right now, I would give it 5 stars but since I don't have another place to compare it to currently I can't determine if it deserves a perfect score or not.

So yes, definitely check this place out if you get the chance, it's worth the time, worth the drive, and worth the money.

Soyo is so great I vow never to give it up, never let it down, never turn around and desert it. Never going to say good bye and never going to tell a lie...

I've been here several times. The food is always on point, and they have great service. The servers check on you and refills on side dishes are free! They always play good music. It's a cool place to grab a bite and some soju with friends.

This is my second time reviewing but I come here all the time now! This is my favorite Korean restaurant in all of Vegas! I got the  (rice cake and dumpling soup) and it was so good! The staff was really nice and attentive as well. Can't wait to come back again :)

I came to this place a few times with friends,and it feels me that it's a litlle be expansive for the quality of food they serve in here.
The thing that really make sense are the drinks,yogurt soju is pretty tasty~!
The servic was nice too.I gonna go back~
Be ready to get the bill , couple minutes after you place the order, the restaurant not even busy, even you can see obviously the server chit chat, they want to kick you out, omg , so baddd!!!!!

Good Korean food, for where it is.  Service is decent.  It was good and quick at first, and the slowed down as our meal progressed.

All of the food was prepared well, to our liking.  Everything traditional tasted as it should.  I really enjoyed the Kalbi Jim, but what really surprised me was this spicy chicken dish with cheese.  I would have never thought about ordering it, but my friend had received it by accident the last time he went, and said that we had to get it.  It was good, and not anything that I would have thought about ordering on my own.  The kalbi, chicken wings, kimchi fried rice, and kimchi pancake were good too.

********Warning**********

I write this with huge disappointment because I frequented this place for the past two years. There clearly was a small piece of dirty plastic in my hot stone beef soup. It's unfortunate that I found this piece of plastic in my mouth at the bottom of the soup after I ingested most of the dish. I asked the server if he could ask the chef where it came from. He came back and said it was probably a chip from the stone pot that I was eating out of. 
At that moment, I knew there was no point on making a bigger issue out of it. If the chef can't even be completely honest with me, there was no point in arguing with them. I simply wanted the truth to what it could possibly be because I want to know what goes into my body. Clearly he accidentally dropped or broke something inside the soup while he was making it. THERE IS NO PLASTIC IN A STONE POT!!!!
If they can't take ownership of mistakes and they aren't careful with what ingredients goes into the food they serve, I definitely will NEVER come back. Beware of what you're eating here if you're brave enough to step into their door.
Amazing place. Pineapple Soju is out of this world. Got #37,#36 and #6. Great prices. Must visit!
Its a cool little spot, good food and caters to the younger crowd. Not that they won't give you the same service if you were older but the decor and ambiance is more for the younger hipster folks.
My favorite Korean restaurant! Food is so delish! Serving is just right. The place is so hip. I'm usually still awake late night, so glad to find a great barstaurant that's still open late.

Delicious food and great service. Will definitely frequent this restaurant in the future. They have a wide variety of dishes (menu is huge) as well as alcoholic beverages. The ambiance is wonderful and it is very authentic.

This is my 2nd time here and still disappointed at the Kimchi fried rice. It was just Kimchi and rice no meat in there making it just taste plan spicy. sigh
The rib shorts was super lite on the flavor, the fried wings was nice and crispy. The little dashes that they give you is ok, had so much better little dashes else where.  The soup taste like spicy Kimchi juice with water =\ no special favor or touch to it.

This was the first Korean spot that I actually enjoyed after moving to Vegas from California. I ordered the Soon Tofu Soup with Beef. The flavor was spectacular--slightly spicy and just the right authentic ingredients to make it a great tofu soup. They add seaweed in this one which I have never tried in any of the soups I've ordered before. It adds a great touch to bring the whole soup together. The only thing that bothered me was that the beef was very chewy and chunky. Soyo could benefit from slicing the beef into smaller pieces. The tofu was also very broken up like it had gotten a good beating before it was served on the table. 

The restaurant not only serves Korean food but also comes equipped with a full bar. Our party of 5 sat at one of the booths and sipped on yogurt soju, which consisted of all soju. There was the tiniest bit of alcohol in it, if it even had any. The Korean servers were young and didn't really know how to "serve". I'm a bit picky on the service, but considering that it was a bar, I didn't put service high up on my priority list as I normally would at any other restaurant. Unfortunately, there was no button attached to the table so we had to flag our server down a couple a times. 

Excellent restaurant. Excellent food. Excellent spot to hang out with friends. Definitely coming back here again!

Nice atmosphere and younger hip crowd and servers.  I ordered the Bulgogi (BBQ style) and it was extremely tough and fatty.  Nothing like the soft and tender bulgogi at Tofu Hut. Service was good however so it somewhat made up for the sub par dish.

I'm Soyo hungry! 

It's a chilly winter night and soondubu (spicy hot tofu soup) was on our radar. We chose this quaint little spot and we're very glad we did! 

Soyo Korean Barstaurant has a cute name and an even cuter romantic atmosphere with a Korean bar charm. Imagine twinkling Christmas lights dangling from the ceiling and the booths tucked away in the back with steps and shutters making them look like little mini apartment rooms. The ambiance is sweet to say the least. 

The complimentary barley tea to sip in little tin bowls is as legit as you can get! So earthy, nutty, and healthy to boot! We love the stuff. 

The banchan offering were all flavorful and authentic. We went for seconds and thirds of the kimchi and the sweet crunchy seaweed snack. They really enhanced our dishes. Flavor rating: 4/5

Here's what we sampled:
Soon Doo Boo JJI Gae (Spicy tofu soup with beef) $8 - the soup base was on the bland side and not very spicy, even though I asked for it to be very spicy. I may consider ordering this dish again, as hot soup cures a lot of winter aliments, yet I might just have to add my own makeshift seasonings (ie: banchan/kimchi, spicy red sauce/sriracha, soy sauce, you name it!) Flavor rating: 3/5

Kim Chi Jyun (Korean traditional kimchi pancake) $7 - thin and super crispy, yet a little tad on the oily side. However great flavor and decent portion makes up for it. Flavor rating: 4/5

Japchae (sweet potato noodles stir fried in sesame oil with vegetables and beef Bulgogi meat) - Great flavor and they really loaded it up with veggies and meat, but the noodles were sparse. I would recommend the dish but we would probably request extra noodles in the future. Flavor rating: 4/5

The portions are decent and the prices are reasonable. Some minor complaints but overall we would return for their yummy Korean bar-style dining!

We love coming to Soyo when we are in town. The atmosphere is relaxed and fun and the food is great. Our favorite is the Cha Dol (thinly sliced brisket). The salad that comes with it is great and we always ask for sesame oil and salt on the side. The fried chicken is also good, as is dooboo kimchi (it is spicy, beware!). It is a barstraunt, so plenty of drinks if interested (lots of flavored soju and makguli).

Below was my previous review couple years ago but since then soyo has gone downhill in a big way - food now tastes half-done/overdone lacking any attractive characteristics.  It often tastes old/dry/rubbery or overly mushy and not very clean (think spoiled cooking oil flavor). Service is rude and perfunctory at best. It's sad to see a good restaurant deteriorating this way. 


Great korean food, unique contemporary menu at a very reasonable price!  They have this great beer - Morimoto soba - a must try if you like dry but fruity beer.

i love this place. there has been an influx of different korean dining options in las vegas lately, but soyo stays at the top of the list; the food is consistently good, and sometimes the different side dishes are a pleasant surprise. they have the best kimchi of anywhere i've been and it's a constant with the side dishes. i always get the kimchi fried rice (you can add spam!), beef kalbi, or the kimchi stew with baby back ribs. the barley tea is always good, and the servers are my favorite people ever. even when it's really busy, we get seated and served very quickly (and, in worst-case scenario, reasonably). the barley tea is an added bonus as well.

I probably come here at least once every two weeks. It is conveinently located right down the street from me.  My boyfriend always orders the kalbi and my favorites are the Haemul Sundubu Jjigae (Spicy tofu soup) and the Spicy Beef soup. I love anything spicy!! 

The service can be slow at time but the staff is very friendly. Good food with great prices. I am always taking my friends and guests here.
We have been here a number of times and every time we have, the food is great the price is not too steep and the service is good.
Love love love this place! Awesome food and they play awesome songs! So happy there's a good Korean restaurant in the southwest area. Don't need to drive to China town!

One very important note: my Korean wife doesn't really love this place! But, I do! (That's what counts, doesn't it?) 
Their chicken both sweet and garlic is delicious!
I love the side dishes & they're always willing to refill. Maybe they could offer more rice, but they'll always give more if you ask
Great staff, awesome decor and delish food makes this place a perfect spot for Korean food.

This is a good place to go with friends for drinking soju and a little noshing.  The food is "Seoul" style, which isn't my favorite, but good in quality.  The staff is helpful but spread a little thin, which I find typical in a lot of Korean places.  It's open late so that is a plus.  Good place to go and meet friends for a drink and some food.

Went for dinner tonight with family and enjoyed very much the japchae, bulgogi, bbq short ribs, chicken wings, and spicy fried rice. The service is good. Prices are good. I would return, next time I'm in town.

I love this Korean Restaurant. Most of the good Asian restaurants are located in the China Town area, Spring Mountain Rd. This one is located on Rainbow, but is always busy. It is a small restaurant, and really cool inside. I haven't tried any other kinds of their food except the spicy seafood hot pot. I had this hot pot 4 times, and loved it every time. 
The service is very good and fast. Their waiters/ waitresses are very friendly, and they always took a good care of us. Their banchans are average compared to other Korean restaurants I have tried before, but they are not important, as long as their main dishes are great, that's what matters. 

TIPs: If you are a big fan of K-pop, this is a place for you, because they have very loud Korean music on most of the time. 
I will definitely come back again and again, and I want to try their Soju once. I have never tried it before.

A+ and good prices.

Pork Belly was served with awesome bitter greens, made a great combo.  Seafood pancake was really good too, full of good stuff.

i love this authentic korean barstaurant! the right size, low light barstaurant was DELICIOUS!  the food and service was GREAT! not knowing what to expect but the awesome reviews a bunch my friends have told me. We ordered 3 things and we're surprise how filling the portions were. Pork cutlet, grilled mackerel, and garlic fried chicken. can't say too much about the bbq flavored pork cutlet and veggies.. but my oh my the grilled mackerel was heavenly. it compares to the black cod at ichiza but bigger portion for the same price!  and garlic fried chicken was equally delicious. these chicken pieces were huge and crunchy! it is definitely a must try! with just these 3 items, youre definitely going to need a take home box. 

can't wait to come back and taste their SOJU! 

=)

I love how they decorated the place!! This place brings back memories of my childhood in Korea. The food is also great! My favorite dishes are cheese chicken katsu, bosam and ramen dukboki. I also love drinking their yogurt soju! MUST TRY EVERYONE!

This was my second time here and this time around was able to order one of the stews as it can feed up to 3-4 people. 

Food was not bad, not the same as i have had it else where. But flavors are all there. The side dishes that they provide were tasty as well.

Staff was friendly and the ambiance was good, except the music might have been too loud. When you can't hear yourself speak then I feel its too loud.

I went here on the strength of the positive yelp reviews. I will chalk up my not so great experience on my ignorance of the Korean culture. I had no idea what I was going to order. The ingredients looked good but I wasn't sure if it would come out unlike what I am used to. I ordered bulgogi(only thing I was sure I would like) and my gf ordered short ribs. They were both good but the bulgogi was not what I expected. Not bad, just not what I'm used to. Have you ever gone to a place and people look at you like wtf? Are you doing here?...that's how I felt 

The place itself seems really cool and hip. Before I left Las Vegas it wasn't there and glad to see a place like it in my neighborhood. I will go back after I do some research and not feel like an outsider idiot...
Help yelpers...I really want to like this place...it's so cool...I wan to spin the wheel and know what I'm winning...lol

Deuces,
Ish

Usually the service and food here are good, this experience was bad. The waitress was rude and when asking if I could have different meat for my dish she said no without a reason, also when asking if I could have fish cakes and kimchi for the sides instead of the other sides like the bean sprouts she ignored my question and just said yeah yeah we have that. And took my menu when I wasn't really done looking at it and left. She checked up on us once and I had to go up to the counter to get a box and the check since we waited so long for the check. I felt that she only wanted to serve the Korean customers there. And it's sad that this might be one of those places that provide better service to their own race. I would tell the manager or the owner of the store that they really need to teach their workers how to have better customer services. I would love to come back and eat this food again, but not sure if I want to after this service.

Great for late night eats!

My girlfriends love this place because they love Korean cuisine (I guess I do too!.lol). My first impression of the joint: I felt as if I teleported to Korea. It was so crazy. The set up of the place is like you're standing in urban Korea; it's pretty legit. There's mini arcade games by the entrance, cozy booths with Korean comics on their shelves, and a swanky dim ambience. The staff is very welcoming and they are very attentive. They serve a traditional ice tea instead of water and it's really refreshing. Foods to suggest would be their bulgogi and their array of Korean ramens and soups. 

Good for lunch and great if you work late at night and you craving wholesome food. I came here a couple times for lunch and once time after I got off work at 1:30am with my friends.

Came here by a friend's recommendation to have some Korean food in vegas. Love the secluded booths and the food. It's a little pricey but the food is good so it's worth it. Will come back again in the future!
Good food. Friendly service. A bit away from the strip. Didn't care too much for the loud music. Reasonable price.

I've been wanting to come to this place more often because of my latest obession with Korean food, but I have either chickened out or haven't been able to find a food adventure partner in the late-night hours of when those Korean food cravings hit. Also, as someone who is not fully familiar with Korean cuisine, I got a little intimidated by the 'barstaraunt-y' feel of this place. The menu is in half korean and half english, with the english being only the descriptions and the korean being only the name of the dish. This made my first attempt at trying Soyo a challenge as I was armed only with a list of korean dishes spelled out in english from my best friend who was teaching in South Korea at the time. Ultimately, my first time trying to venture out of my sundubu/kalbi/bulgogi triumvirate of Korean dishes ended up with me trying their "milky soup with oxtail and beef pieces" dish that I had to flavor with salt myself. Needless to say, I didn't know what I was doing and ended up with a really salty, milky oxtail soup where my comrades stuck to what they knew and got some really yummy bulgogi soup in a steaming hot clay pot. 

The second time, however, I came armed with my actual best friend who just got back from teaching in Korea and he not only translated what was in the dishes but ordered for us and we ended up getting filled up on much less than what I spent last time. This time around we got the kimchee fried rice and a spicy version of the beef rib stew with vegetables and that was more than enough with the banchan to fill us up. The stew was delicious: sweet with a soy sauce-based soup, with carrots, onions, and other veggies. The meat was definitely falling-off-the-bone tender, but even though we ordered it spicy, the heat wasn't memorable at all. The kimchee fried rice was sticky, spicy, and eggy--everything I expected and so yummy all the same. The banchan was pretty decent, however the egg omelet thing was way too salty for either of us to take, even for our asian palates. My friend commented that the kimchee was really good, but the daikon was too sweet. For some reason, as our experience progressed, it seemed like a party was growing inside the restaurant and I started to realize why they call it a 'barstaraunt'. It really does turn into a bar/club-like atmosphere after a certain hour, and considering it was around 11 on a Monday night, I'd say that's pretty typical for the young asian american crowd on a holiday week. 

I want to keep coming back to this place, but my friend keeps insisting that a lot of the dishes they charge quite a bit for are actually cheaper and easier to make at home. Seeing as I'm still a major newbie at the Korean food thing, I may come back a few more times until my friend shows me the ropes of how to insert some Korean cuisine into my kitchen.
Food was good and decently priced. Also in a quiet area in a plaza that has good parking

I love Soyu. I could come here and eat spicy pork and Korean chicken wings every day. Service is a little lacking but they make up for it  with delicious food. Kimchi is very fresh and delicious as well
Love this place. Go to restaurant. Open late. And taste like clean home cooking regardless the hour. yummy bulgogi broth yumms

We finally tried this place since it was the closest Korean place we can get to besides Chinatown.  Unfortunately they didn't have the BBQ chicken my husband likes at regular Korean BBQ places.  The server misheard my order (I wanted the squid dish) but only had the regular pork belly and sprouts dish.  It was very good.  May come back to try the actual squid one in the future.  The menu was quite extensive and there were so many new things I would like to try.

Best Bibimbop I've had in Las Vegas so far. There's was no meat and I didn't even notice. Can't wait to go back and try the potato pancakes and the seafood pizza. Besides the food, the ambience was welcoming.

Bland Bland Bland!!! Don't understand soooo many good reviews about this place.. Drove by here a million time and I never want to try it til my niece told me its good(shouldn't have listen to her) hehe.. 
We order the potstickers and it was alright, a little chewy and not much filling..
Bibimbap was just ok, never a fan of it cuz they don't give you much meat and too much veggies(meat to veggie ratio is way off) not just here everywhere is the same.. I'm a MEAT lover...
Tofu with pork and kimchi soup was yucky yucky!! I had to put so much salt for flavor and there was no raw egg.. Don't order this people!!!
The chicken wings was GOOD, got half and half of two different sauce. I'm NOT coming back to this restaurant ever again..
The place is small and decor was ok, nothing special or wow about here..
BTW.. This is not kid friendly restaurant, the music was way too loud..

Had kalbi $17 and korean style wings(t2) $12 and it was great. Pricing may run a little high than any other normal dine in restaraunt, but portion sizing is very generous. The side dishes were okay.  Food tasted very delicious. Customer service was great too. I would come back here just for their wings though.

Had been meaning to try this place out for a while and glad we finally did!  The service was really attentive and we didn't feel awkward asking questions about the food (we had a lot!).  The decor definitely reminded me of Seoul - I was pretty surprised how they were able to recreate the vibe of restaurants there in a strip mall in Vegas.  

We tried fried dumplings, garlic chicken wings, spare ribs and the spicy ramen soup.  Everything was really good - next time we will be more adventurous with our choices. I'd definitely go back.
Great food and excellent service!! I highly recommend this place. My pregnant wife can only seem to eat their foods!

Pretty cool Korean restaurant our friend took us to.  The environment is really nice and cozy.  The food itself was 4 stars though.  It was really good but I have had better.  They didn't have the grills at the tables like many korean restaurants do either.  

Overall a nice place worth trying.  5 star environment but 4 star food.
You can enjoy great food and drinks with good music. Different flavor sojus and variety of rice beverages. They are open late so that's also a plus. You'll love this place. You won't regret it.

Went before the dinner crowd at about 5:30pm on a friday, no waiting, we were seated right away.  The Maa Neul chicken wings were to die for.  Had the soon dubu jigae seafood, came with standard bon Chan side dishes, everything was delicious!

By far the best Korean restaurant. It isn't over priced like many other Korean restaurants. I live on the edge of the northwest side of Las Vegas, but I don't mind the drive because it's the best here.

I have been going to this place for almost 3 years now. I'm very obsessed with the authentic Korean food they serve. Even my friends who don't know much about the culture have fallen in love with the place!

Soyo Korean Barstaurant is a hidden gem in the Southwest part of Las Vegas! Miss this place sooooo much!

My wife and I used to go to Soyo at least 2x a month when we lived in Las Vegas, because it was 10 minutes away from us. It is always open pretty late too, so we went for lunch, dinner, or a late night meal. We always ordered the same thing every time we came to eat: I would order the "L.A. Gaal Bi" (this is the actual name of the dish there) and my wife would get the "Soon Doo Boo JJI Gae" (this is the spicy tofu soup and she would get it with seafood). My short ribs were always pretty tasty, although they may not be the best that I've ever had. That dish only costs $15 though, which is cheaper than a lot of other Korean restaurants in town. The seafood tofu soup, on the other hand, is one of the best ones we've ever tried and it's only $8! So you definitely won't break the bank at Soyo!

We've gone a couple other times, and tried some of the other dishes, which we weren't as fond of, like the "Kong Naa Mool O Jing Uh Saam Gyup Saal" (bean sprout and pork belly casserole). First of all, this dish has the longest name ever, and it is an enormous dish, but the taste is just ok. Also, it's one of the more expensive dishes on the menu at $23.00.

Anyway, this was always one of our favorite places to go eat when we were in Las Vegas, and now we miss it dearly. We try to make time for it when we fly back to Vegas every once in a while, but I wish there was a Soyo in the Bay Area. Affordable and tasty. Good service, and really cool divey atmosphere. Check it out!
Great price! Good food! What more can I say! Best Korean food in town. Highly recommend the short ribs and bulgogi! And of course you have to chase it down with some hite! Awesome place!

I've totally slept on Soyo.  I've never even heard of it until I went with some fellow Yelpers who frequent the joint and I'm so glad I did.  InstaFan!!

Everything on the menu looked really good, but I decided to go with the Dolsot Bimimbap ($9).  If you have never had this, it's served in a stone pot and rice, egg, veggies, and beef.  I've only had Bimimbap at a few other places (so I am far from being an expert), but this is probably the best I've tried.  The rice that hardened from the heated stone pot is seriously the best part!  

I got to sample a few other things too and I was totally impressed:

Chicken Wings -
  These were doused in some amazing marinade.  I do not have the slightest clue as to what it is (perhaps it's some homemade concoction of some sorts), but it was definitely memorable!  The wings itself were huge too!  These came off some ripped chickens!

Budae Jigae (I totally did not know what the stew was since I didn't order it, so I had to rely on a fellow Yelpers review for the name)-
   This is what is going to bring me back to this place!  The portion of this thing was out of control (perfect for sharing).  I honestly do not even know what was in it:  noodles, Spam, and pieces of bacon.  Whatever it was, it was full of goodness!  It had a spice to it that gave it an awesome kick.  Not too spicy though so you can actually enjoy the taste.

Pros:
*  decently priced
* filling portions
* authentic food
* endless Barley tea in some tin bowl (I love it!)

Cons:
*  The only con I can think of is that I slept on this place for too long... If you haven't been, you definitely have got to try it.  I'm so taking my gf here the next chance I get.

Tips:
*  Come hungry!
* Yes, they have flavored Soju for those wondering.
