As a frequent customer you tend to have the same thing over and over again. I had the samgyupsal and bibim naengmyun. Both dishes were arranged in a nice manner. 
Samgyupsal - came pre seasoned with the salt sesame oil with a slight crisp that would resemble having a thick cut bacon slice. Salad was paired with this dish to counter the oily factor to this dish. 

Bibim naengmyun- a good spicy kick to your palate and you bite into the buckwheat noodles with s shred of beef to top it. 

Final analysis. I recommend the samgyupsal and the kalbi. 

Not huge fan of the bibim naengnmyun. Usually comes with your mustard and vinegar to help balance your dish.

For a first timer, this place is yum-o!!  The sides could be better but I'm sure their selections changes over time.  

We ordered the spicy seafood soup.  This was really good but my spice tolerance is a bit low.  I had 2 small bowls and that was all I can take.  The boyfriend finished it.

I ordered the beef bulgogi bowl and it was a nice sweet contrast to the spicy seafood soup. 

Everything was seasoned and cooked really well.  I really liked the barley tea that they provided.  I wish I ordered soju but I'll wait for the next time.

I will return!!

Had the worst experience dining here last night. It wasn't always like this, but this is the second time the service really lacked. Took 15-20m to take our order. Restaurant isn't busy as it usually is. One of the guy servers just looked at us and looks away. One of our dishes, the meat was undercooked. Servers didn't bother to check on us. Took 20m to get refill for water. We kept trying to get a server's attention to get us more water. The same male employee just looks at us and looks away. So one of us had to get up go to the front to ask for water, napkins, and to-go containers. Customer service was terrible.
tasty?ice cream is sooo cute? food is tasty and cheap! One of the best Korean restaurants in Vegas

Stopped by for lunch during a family vacation to Vegas. I haven't had good Korean food in Vegas for years and Soyo was no exception. Galbitang was the worst I ever had. Meat tasted like freeze dried beef. How can meat that had been boiled in water for hours be so dry? I could really taste the msg in the soup. Spicy chicken wings were better. Haemul Jjambbongtang was just ok. Service was poor. We were there around 4PM when the restaurant was not busy and no one came around to ask how the food was or if we needed anything. Only thing that was good about the restaurant was the decor. If this restaurants as in LA, it would not last too long.

Soyo is a fun neighborhood spot that has successfully created a fun bar atmosphere whilst serving great korean food.

I've never been to Korea so what I'm about to say makes no sense. 
 
Soyo makes me feel Korean the moment I walk in. I've always wanted to be Korean so it's like a dream come true. I'm partially joking... I went through high school listening to K-pop so the fact they play nothing but K-pop is enough of a reason for me to come back time and time again. 

Lucky for me, their food is fantastic also. They serve all the typical Korean dishes that most of  us are familiar with and some + American favorites such as french fries and chicken wings. 

My favorite dishes to order;
Kalbi(short ribs)
Soon Dubu Jjigae (tofu soup)
Dduk Bokki( spicy rice cakes)
both the spicy and fried chicken wings 
bibimnaengmyeon (cold buckwheat noodles)

I'm here a few times a month since it's so close to my house and open late. I have yet to have a terribly bad experience. 

Service is a hit or miss...Miss most of the time...
This is probably because I'm not actually Korean :( But that's ok...I am not needy. Keep feeding me delicious food and continue to play the awesome tunes that you do... I will be a loyal fan.

So  I finally returned to this wonderful Korean outpost and I can happily say my main concern was addressed (this time we got spectacular service) and the food was as good as ever.

Fair warning though they mean spicy! I got sweet and spicy pork ribs and was reveling in their volcanic glory when my companion got his ribs and the waiter said "watch out those are really hot." 

They were like experiencing Pompeii first hand with your tongue; except delicious and not ashy.

I do have to wonder if the service was so good because the staff wanted to see if they'd successfully murdered us with Korean Spicy Goodness...

Wow! We came tonight for dinner after a long day at the park. We got seated very quickly, which was great, we made it right before the dinner rush.

We usually sit outside buy decided to sit inside tonight. The server came to take our order and she asked if we will be getting the seafoos pancake tonight... she smiled and said "I know you always order it, you usually sit at the patio." It made us feel great, that she remembered us, we only came twice before.

As usual, the food came out quickly and tasted great.

We will be back often!

I love this restaurant. It's one of my favorites that my boyfriend and I go to often. The food is great. Have yet to find a dish that isn't delicious. They have a good size menu with a lot of selections. But when we've tried everything on the menu, they also have new specials every once in a while. New dishes that maybe a new dish that'll stay on the menu. Service is great. Can be slow when it gets busy but, what restaurant isn't? They're very tentative to their customers. It does have a small dining area but they have seats outside on the patio.

I love that they are open late! Seafood pancake is definitely a MUST!!! YUMMM!!! Yogurt soju pairs wonderfully with all the delicious food. Also YUMMM!! There are different flavors of yogurt soju available. Will try others in the future.  Ordered 3 dishes to share with the husband and it was a good amount of food. Bibimbap was tasty although I Would have wanted more veggies.  Kalbi was cooked perfectly with great flavor. Atmosphere is pretty chill with a mixture of American pop & Kpop music blasting. Kind of a small place in my opinion (aprox 12 tables or so inside) with additional outside seating. Great little spot for date night or just dinner with friends.
Food was always good. But last review got low stars for extremely rude staff, now, been back twice, and staff is excellent now.

This based on my second visit here with a group of friends on 7.24.16. Overall cool Korean restaraunt with an upbeat vibe and neat quirky decor. Main dinning room is seperated by elevated booths on both sides and communial tables and chairs in the middle. Defintely a young crowd of millennials are spotted at this place next door to Oyshi Sushi and just across the way from Serenade Coffee Bar. However the food is really good and the service can be a bit slow depending if they are busy, but they have been consistent and they make sure we are ok. This is not your typical AYCE Korean BBQ joint but the dishes are good portion and great to order a variety of different dishes to share with a group of friends and family. Cool alternative from all the other Korean BBQ restaraunts in Vegas!

(I'm half Korean, been to many K restaurants) Favorite Korean restaurant, it has the best service/food/price combination (in my humble opinion lol). It environment has modern pop Korean music, retro decor, and a young Korean wait staff (feels authentic). If you're looking for a more quiet traditional restaurant, this isn't the place for you. The music is on the louder side, vibe is for bringing friends and having a good time!

The seafood soup tasted rotten and the mussels and shrimp were rotten! When we mentioned to manager, he made us waited for a while to show up and without any apology, He took off a few dollars from this $25 dish! We suggest you  do not come here!

So from the yelp pics I was a little reluctant to give this place a shot. Decided to try out this place I have to say this place is nicely put together the service was good and food was really good we had the kimchi pancake, bim bim bop and the bulgogi all were excellent. Drinking out of the tin cup was kind of weird 

Definitely would go back!!!

this place is so cute! its a bit out of the way but totally worth it. =) came here with some friends after reading all the good reviews on yelp. we ordered the bibimbap, soon doo-boo, and bulgolgi. it was delicious! everything was piping hot and the bibimbap had a nice crunch to it. we also shared a bottle of yogurt soju....soooooo good but definitely dangerous. service was great. will definitely come back when i get a craving for korean food!

If I'm not mistaken Soyo was on dirty dinning sometime last year? Oh well I guess, since their food is pretty good. I came here with a party of 4 including myself, been hearing so many good things about them and so many check ins from all kinds of people. Our group ordered kalbi, bulgogi and 2 other beef dishes I can't remember and all of them were really good. I'm curious to try the other menu options. The inside is kinda weird, but I guess typical Korean? No mean infringe on their culture, but there were also Christmas lights around the restaurant? The service was pleasant and I did enjoy the overall experience probably making this one of my favorite Korean spots in town, too bad they don't do AYCE Korean BBQ, that would be awesome. I would highly suggest for the owner to do it cuz their meats are spectacular.

Best Korean food in Vegas.  Quickly become one of my favorite restaurants and I love going there every chance I can.  I love the ambience, the food is great, and the kimchi is awesome.  I would recommend this place to anyone.

Service was slow, but food was yummy & didn't take very long after initial order. Good kimchi, short ribs & steak salad dish were good and filling, not really greasy which is typical of certain Korean dishes. I will definitely be back.

The bi bim bap was ok but the seafood pancake was excellent!  However the service was lacking due to the fact that they rarely came to our table to check up on us......we may come back but because of their mediocre service we'll most likely go elsewhere, besides there are too many Korean restaurants in the area to try.
Great Korean food!!! I've never ordered anything that I didn't like. My favorite is the spicy seafood tofu soup.
My go to for neighborhood Korean food.  The bulgolgi and seafood tofu soup are my favourites.  Best of all, because the food is mainly cooked in the kitchen, you don't end up smelling like your meal.

Nice restaurant with a Bar-ish feel. I love all the booths along the wall. Great tofu soup.

I also ordered the kimchi pancake which was too greasy!! All in all it was good and I will come back.

Soyo think you've had good Korean food?  (humor courtesy of my boss DCW).  We came here for lunch and had the bi bim bap, short ribs, and chicken wings.  Wings were delicious, a little sweet and sour.  Bi bim bap was just like I remembered.  Food was quick and our server was friendly and made sure we had everything we needed.  I will definitely be back

No japchae though (my fav), but i guess it's important to try different things.

The food was good but I didn't like the fact they added the tip in the bill when I had only a party of four I can understand if I had a party of 6 or more. So check your bill make sure you don't tip them twice.
Second visit and still super good..  Definitely appreciate the consistency, not only with the food, but also service..!
Definitely coming back here again. Try the lychee soju!

Great refreshing food! There are a few food items that are not my favorite, like Korean blood sausage. Really like the barley tea for some reason, refreshing. Would really recommend this place! Garlic Korean style chicken wings are very tasty and deliver a pleasant crunch. Other favorites are dumplings, Kimchi fried rice, mozzarella corn, Korean potato pancake, cheese Don Katsu, and the assortment of Kimchi. Friendly and helpful service!
Fantastic atmosphere and food all around! My favorite Korean restaurant in Vegas by far. The service is also excellent. Definitely coming back!!

If I could only have one thing here it would be the Lychee Soju. For 12 bucks in a big bottle that suits the thirst of two people. It was bliss. 

I ordered to go so as I waited I tried it at the suggestion of the waiter. I tipped him extra because his suggestion was spot on.

now for the food. 

For a togo order I got more than I could have imagined. The portions were huge, the food spicy and just mouth watering. Literally. I shouldn't have gotten it to go. I should have stayed eaten the spicy soup and beef and washed it down with that sweet sweet Soju. 

The place is tiny but it's so cute. And they have little kid size arcade machines. The music was wicked awesome and the atmosphere fun and modern. This place is a must!
I love this place!!!!! An all around great place to c9me out and hwmg out with friends. Good service good food, will definitely come back!

Best korean restaurant in Vegas!! Ive been to korean and my some of my friends are korean so I can honestly say that this is the best korean cuisine restaurant in vegas! Great service from the servers and the food is delicious! I love their korean seafood pancake, bbq pork belly and seafood casserole! I would come back and bring friends and family!
thought my ramen was really good and really tasty. The server was alright but not the friendliest, although it was busy. I would go again for sure.

Ahn yong ha SOYO! I'm bummed that it took me so long to find this place. It's hands down the best Korean restaurant that I've been to in Vegas. Comfort food with great flavor, and excellent customer service to go along with it. I will definitely be coming back! 

Recommendations:
*Soon Doo Boo Gae (spicy tofu soup with choice of beef, seafood or pork) 
*Naap Jaak Maan Doo (flat dumplings with ground beef and pork, clear noodles and vegetables)
Service was great. Food was great. Soju was awesome. Always busy. A lil cozy place:-) wish they deliver though!

My experience with Soyo was disappointing.  I ordered two items from the tapas section of the menu--chicken gizzards with garlic and onion and son doo boo.  The chicken gizzards were good, chewy but that's the nature of the meat.  The son doo boo is supposed to be in beef broth.  The water the two pieces of tofu rested in shouldn't be referred to as broth.  Broth connotes some type of meat/fish flavor.  This had none.  It was merely a watery dish with a side of hot dipping sauce.

It was the wrong day to go to Soyo.  The place is very small.  The tables are such that it's not a good place for a person eating alone.  I was there a little after 5:30 and there were only a few people in the restaurant.  Within a very short time, young people getting dinner before going to EDC came in and I was taking up a table that could seat four or even six.  There was an error with my order and rather than have them bring the correct item ordered, I hurriedly finished and paid the bill so someone else could have the table.

There are too many good choices out there.  Soyo won't be a do over for me.

Soyo is awesome! Have been there a few times. I really like the set up of the restaurant. The booths make it so people can't hear your conversations. 

The kimchee fried rice is amazing as is the spicy pork dish. I like that they give you "ban chan," the little dishes that come with your meal.

ROGUE MORIMOTO SOBA ALE ON DRAFT?!! WHat?!! Also the Lychee Soju is like syrup from the gods.  

The service is normally pretty good.
Never leave hungry and everything is affordable and delicious. I always get a Hite with my meal; the beer is the best Korean beer.

First off, we were all excited to eat here because of all of the great reviews and it was my wife's Birthday. When we got there, it was not busy at all. The server took our order. We all got our food except the birthday girl. We thought, well maybe its still cooking. We waited for almost 40 min and still no soup. Finally I someone came up to check up on us and I told them that my wife didn't get her soup yet. Another server came back to us and told me that they forgot to check up on our order and that it will be out shortly. We were already done eating. I didn't hear an apology or anything so I told her to bring to us in a take out container.  I was so upset, I just wanted to get out of there.  The kalbi wasn't cooked all the way through and it was still pink. Most of the pieces were all fat so my daughter couldn't really eat it. Now I know to go somewhere else.

Came here for the Max Brenner after party with fellow Yelpers!  What a great little korean restaurant.  The decor and theme is supposed to be hip, a drinking place whcih serves food to satisfy the munchies.  

Since I am not a big drinker, I just partook in the food!  Our group ordered oden (fish cake soup), thinly sliced beef with leeks (?), chicken gizzard, korean style fried chicken, and budae jigae (army base stew).

Everything tasted great!  The sliced beef was stir fried with garlic and eaten with a leek salad.  The chicken gizzards were crunchy, not really my cup of tea though.  The fried chicken had super crispy skin and dipped in a sweet sauce.  The best thing about the chicken however, was the side of sweet, pickled radish that came with it: crisp, tart, sweet, and crunchy.  The budae jigae was spicey and contained a mish mash of ramen, hot dog, sausage, vegetables.  Supposidly, this dish was created by soldiers, who put whatever they had into the stew.  Everything was very warming and filling, especially the stew, perfect for one of the coldest nights in Vegas.

Service was good, all you can drink pitchers of barley tea were brought to the table.  The biggest surprise was the bill.  For nine people, the total came out to be $100.  I found it to be a great bargain for great korean comfort food.
simply love this place, authentic, very reasonably priced abd great portions..highly recommend!!!

Yum!  I FINALLY got to try this place last week for a super late night dinner.

1 star = They're open late.  So if you're craving Korean after 9pm, go to Soyo!  They even have a full bar.  So you can even get your drink on too.  Remember, 21 and over at night time!

2 stars = cheap prices.  Unbelievable and unbeatable prices!

3 stars =  for all the kim chee and side goodies they pass out on top of your meal!

4 stars = for their hot stone Bibimbab.  My rice was crispy,  my egg was runny but had crispy edges, and there was lot of veggies in the dish.  I wish there was more meat though.  Yum!  I was definitely satisifed.

I have yet to try other dishes here.  I'll definitely be back!

Yelp Challenge! Started 8/20/2011 (62/365).

Took a much anticipated trip into Soyo for date night with my hubby. 

We were instructed to sit wherever we liked so we chose a nice private booth. It's a pretty small place. I think there's only about 12 tables. The atmosphere and decor are very cool. Much better than expected from the average Korean place. 

The service was excellent throughout but slow considering we were 1 of 3 total tables. Guess that's just how they operate. Pretty laid back. 

We were greeted with complimentary rice water/iced tea concoction. Not my "cup of tea" but my husband loved it. We started with lychee soju. It was pure ecstasy! They even chill all the glasses/tin drinking vessels. The flavored soju is $12 for an approx. 20 oz. bottle. The lychee is magical. We also had the pear. This may have been better of we didn't have the lychee first. The pear soju had too strong of an alcohol taste and was gritty with pear pulp. No thank you. 

After great debate, we decided on the kimchi fried rice, Korean BBQ short ribs (aka kalbi), and the mixed seafood pancake. Furthermore, we received all of the complimentary Korean apps. They served radishes, potatoes, kimchi, fish cakes, and a mysterious crunchy rice noodle in a creamy yogurt/mayo sauce. No pickled cucumbers!! Boo! My favorite. The kimchi fried rice was excellent! It was spicy, flavorful, and topped with an overhard egg. I, of course, would have preferred an over medium egg. The kalbi was ok. It was cut too thick. Very chewy and difficult to eat. The flavor was good though! The blackened onions and cabbage underneath coated in beef drippings was the best part. The pancake was crispy on the outside and slightly gooey on the inside. It was served HOT! Which I like. It came with a very tasty mystery sauce. The menu lists items as "Korean tapas" but they are portioned for 3-4 people. We only ordered 3 items and we were spent!! We even packed some to take home. 

Total bill for 2 bottles of soju and 3 items was $62...$74 with tip. 

I would highly recommend drinking at this place and killing some snackage while you are at it. However, it won't be the best Korean food you've had.
Great food, the bulgogi and chicken were bomb and our waitress Sara was super attentive for our orders!

I've been here over 10 times. But nothing stands up. Food is too Salty.... Dish is so small Over price!  Service is very slow .sever are drinking at cashier or with friends at bar... But no choice I still go coz no restaurants open the late unless you wanna drive to springmt
sooooo good?tasty??? I like the pot with spam!!! and ice cream over there. it is one of the best Korean restaurants in Vegas!

My sister takes me here for lunch. We always get the bibimbap. The little side dishes are great and make every bite different and exciting. We have tried many of the dishes and everything is so tasty. Try the gizzards, squid, chicken wings, mackarel, corn, salad... You can't go wrong. We always get so full with the savory we don't have room for dessert...someday. The service is always quick and friendly. We have never had a bad experience...highly recommend!
Favorite Korean bbq spot in town. So unique and delicious ! A fun place to eat and very affordable prices !

I have been wanting to try Soyo for a while now. To me, it had a very authentic Korean feel and I enjoyed the experience a lot. I had the kimchee pancake and cold spicy noodles. Both were excellent, and the cold noodles were super spicy, even for a spicy lover like myself. The side dishes were typical, but nothing to really write home about. My boyfriend had the bibimbap and he was not that impressed, but we have concluded that he is not really a Korean food fan. I would definitely come back, but likely without the bf.

Upping to 4 stars thanks to their fully equipped, well maintain restroom: a working toilet, sink, mirror, hand soap, air freshener, plunger, bowl scrubby stick thingamabob, baby fold down changing station, paper towel sensor dispenser, and a huge trash can with a top.  Only complaint is that the trash bin's lid is one of those door with bit of restriction, so it'll need an extra push to dump your trash in there.  I usually like an open trash can next to the door after a hand wash, so i can dump my paper towel in there when handling a door knob.

They took us in even though it was at 2:30am just before closing.  Dick move on us, but we were in the mood for some Spicy Ramen. This time I notice the broth has more of that hot dog taste than i wanted since i was burping it all night. Still good though.  My buddy ordered the Kalbi Jjim; germonstrous size beef ribs in a sweet soy base soup, finished with fried stripped eggs, carrots, sesame seed, green onions, and i think seaweed.  The sauce goes great with rice because it gives the tongue a break from all that spiciness from the bancha and ramen.

Music is not soo much in the face today.  Could be because we were the only ones there.  Oh and Black Eyed Peas on repeat..  ew.

Alright same owners as Oyshi Sushi just a few doors down, Andy (nicest guy) who manages Oyshi gave the suggestion to check out their new spot... Soyo. I came in a group of 7 and got the larger booth to the right upon entrance which worked perfectly. The decor is alright nothing too overdone but nothing to write home (Yelp) about, but the big plus for me was the chalk board wall that they let you draw on if you want just keep the words clean. The service is a few of the overflow employees from Oyshi which i have always received great service so no complaints there. The Soju was tasty and decent portions for the money at $12 per order and feeding 7 i think we managed almost 2 shots per order for everybody which was  a nice surprise. The different flavors was excellent but i think the lychee was the favorite among my group. The food was pretty solid for more like bar style food rather than a full on meal. The soups were tasty and served in generous portion, the Korean style pancake was very tasty as well, but my favorite without doubt was the chili/honey wings... coated in a thick honey and chili paste that i could have put on my napkin and eaten. 
All in all i will say 
-Food 8.5-9 / 10 
-Atmosphere 7.5-8 / 10 
-Service 9 / 10 
-Value 9 / 10 
Soyo does it right for an evening out among friends for some light eating and Soju and great conversation. I think that the management/ owners of Oyshi and Soyo have a good recipe going for how to present a restaurant and deliver with their customers. Many kudos their direction from me.

Fantastic and traditional place!!
Staff is great and good is fantastic. Very traditional, again, but it is fun to try new stuff! Menu is huge - lots of things to try!

Husband and I made it over last Sunday and loved it.  Couldn't get over how developed that part of town is!    Definitely think this is the sharpest, most interesting place in that area...

Inside, they've done a  nice job of tricking up the interior to make it feel less strip mall.  I loved the atmosphere although the booths weren't very comfortable nor were they sound buffered - we could hear every word of the conversations around us...

I'd made a short list of items (okay, it was too long) that I wanted to make sure we tried...

We started with the mandu - needed some seasoning but that's what dippping sauce is for -- the filling and portion size was generous.  I'm a sucker for dumplings and love how every culture has one - and I love em all.  

We had the buckwheat noodle soup - it will be coming off the menu as soon as temperatures come down and I've been telling my husband about this dish from EJo... I was thrilled to see it on Soyo's menu.  I had him taste it before adding the vinegar/mustard - he pronounced it flat...I swirled in the magic ingredients and this time his eyes sparkled - it's his kind of dish --  light, bright, surprising, complex but simple.  I loved their version.

We had their KFC (actually the spicy garlic wings) - these were sticky, ooey, gooey delicious - and I normally am not a wing fan...but I thought these were yummy.

We also tried their rice wine - it comes in a bowl with a ladle...and it's addictive.  Light alcohol content, cold, sweet, a little sparkly, think unfiltered sake spritzer or new wine.  Delicious.  (And enough for two to share...or not)

I didn't realize how wonderful Hite beer is until Sunday either -- it's got a touch of sweetness-- perfect for spicy Korean food.  I think Hite is probably my favorite beer right now...

We also tried their kimchee pancake.  Great, but could have been crispier, downright soggy in the middle...but we ate it all with relish.  Sort of hard to complain about when you've pretty much licked the plate clean.

All in all, it was a great first experience...we probably should have tried their bulgogi, but we'll do that the next time - because we will definitely go back.

My favorite Korean restaurant in the city! What I always order: Soon Dubu and Bi Bim Bap. The staff doesn't ask you what spice level, it just comes out the standard Korean hot - which is amazing. 

There is also those small app plates that they give before the courses. They change from time to time which makes me think that they are homemade and fresh. 

I really like the decor too. I like my privacy so I usually take a booth spot. 

I haven't had a chance to play the video game machines that they have in the front but I will one day. I wonder if they have the old school Street Fighter... do people still put a quarter up to save their spot? Ahhh, the good old days.

My family and I were looking for a restaurant to eat for Mother's Day. We looked on yelp and this place had great reviews.

Customer Service- 2.5 in the beginning 

I know it was Mother's Day but it wasn't as packed compared to other locations. When we first got in, there was no greeting, we were completely ignored. I had to go ask if they had seats. 

Customer Service-  10 :D  the rest of our lunch
Once we got seated, our service was on point.

We ordered so much food! What we really liked the most was the pork cutlets, the fish, the kimchi soup,and kimchi fried rice .
We will be going back here again!!

The best Korean restaurant (I mean barstaurant) in town. The ban chan are all so fresh. I know, it's ironic to say kimchi can be fresh since it's fermented but it's crispy and just the right amount of spicy and zest. Also had to try the sundubu and can honestly say the flavors were there. I usually go to Tofu Hut but now have a new go to place for tofu soup. The tofu was sooooo smooth it literally melted in my mouth and usually sundubu can be watered down because of the soft tofu disintegrates, but despite the softness, the tofu kept its shape and did not dilute the soup. Been wanting to come to this place for a year now and now kick myself for taking so long to actually make it. Service was also very gracious, as they took back a dish we thought was something else without a grumble.  It started getting busy and the gal handled almost all the tables. The guy could have been better, but more for her sake than ours as we were already almost done with our late dinner!

This place is amazing! Tried it for the first time last night. We got the squid, spicy pork ribs, and Kim chi fried rice. Everything was on point including the service. They seem to use the team service method. Which even the manager was highly involved. The overall experience was awesome and we will be back really soon.

I feel that I'm often the last one to try a lot of popular restaurants in Vegas, and I'm glad that I've finally checked this one off my list.

Soyo is a Korean restaurant in Southwest Las Vegas. I had trouble seeing the name on the facade at first, but it's on the southern corner of a building that it shares with a few other businesses, perhaps most notably Oyshi Sushi. Not many people were utilizing the outside seating area, which is expected in the summer. I didn't actually find out where the "bar" of the "barstaurant" is, but I'm sure it has to exist.

Anyway, the main indoor dining area has a pleasant ambiance. It has an interesting feel with the concrete flooring, largely pale wooden walls, bookshelves, and rather dated appliances including a television set and some arcade games. There are some rather charming booths that are elevated slightly above the ground, but our large group took up a table or two on the floor. The largely K-pop music wasn't stifling in loudness, but it's noticeable during conversation. I really liked the cushions that they provide because it never came to mind even once during the meal that I was sitting on a wooden bench.

You'll definitely want to drink something here, even if it's non-alcoholic. The complimentary barley tea is my favorite rendition of this drink so far. The barley flavor is cleaner than what most places serve, but it doesn't taste watered down. I probably could have finished the entire pitcher by myself. By the way, they didn't serve it in bowls, which I'm sure would have been awkward.

I also had a couple shots of the yuzu soju. It's not very alcohol-heavy, but it's sweet and clear with a wonderful yuzu flavor. If you haven't enjoyed this particular type of citrus before, this is as good a chance as any.

The food was good overall. The Japchae ($10) with bulgogi (+$2) was really delicious. Really smooth noodles with egg, beef, and thinly sliced veggies. I would order it again. The soondubu ($8) with my choice of seafood is a bargain compared to most other places and tastes delicious even without the egg, which is either an add-on or was misplaced somewhere by the wait staff. Loved the broth, which came out mild per my request, as well as the silky tofu and the various seafood bits (shrimp, mussel, clams, octopus). It's my favorite soondubu in Vegas so far.

The LA-style galbi ($15) was good too, but I typically prefer a sweeter marinade on the meat. There may also be some small inconsistencies with the cooking temperature due to wide variations in how they cut apart the meat, not that the texture was at all tough or that I've gotten sick or anything. I kinda wish that I'd opted for the seemingly popular garlic chicken wings now instead, but at least there's always next time.

The complimentary banchan (side dishes) were a bit of a mixed bag. I really liked the kimchi and I enjoyed the broccoli, but I disliked the surprising crunch of one of the items that looked to me like sliced skin-on tofu. Also, the crunchy chunks of some juicy radish-like root vegetable seemed atypical and out of place, and nobody ever asked if we wanted seconds.

I also managed to sample a few other items from around the table. The seafood pancake (haemul pajeon, or however they anglicized it here) was delicious, with prominent octopus pieces in at least my chunk of the pancake. The dduk bok e (from the first page of the menu) tasted pretty good and wasn't too spicy for me, but I'm just not a fan of the rice dumplings. I'd describe their texture as a "mushy" chewy, which I'm sure is intentional but just isn't my favorite thing to have in my mouth. I also enjoyed a sample of the beef from what appeared to be a bulgogi with dressed chopped lettuce.

I'd love to return to Soyo to try more of their dishes. There's not much competition in terms of Korean food in this particular part of town, but they're doing a great job regardless.

(UPDATE 1/8/16: I'm not ready to add the 5th star quite yet, but some dishes that I tried for the first time included included fantastic corn cheese, delicious kalbi sam gyup sal, good bo saam, and a a nice spicy soup that I think was boo dae jji gae. I also enjoyed the laa bok e, which is like the dduk bok e but with instant ramen noodles instead of the sticky rice cake. Also, the beef chive salad was good again, and the LA galbi seemed to be sweeter and therefore tastier than last time.)

While I enjoy spicy food, sometimes their food can be a little overwhelmingly spicy. I have to constantly sniffle while eating here... BUTTTTTT I will sit there and sniffle all night long because beyond the spice is an amazing authentic Korean taste. I normally get one of their noodle dishes - it has spicy rice cake, ramen, fish cake, egg, and I like to add tofu for a little added protein in there. I love love love the flavor. It has a sweet and spicy taste to it, and the rice cake it perfectly chewy.

I also got one of their soups, and while it was a little too spicy, I like that they give you more broth.. So I have my friends take the first round of soup and I dig in once they bring more broth so it's less spicy. 

I've never been disappointed! Always leave with a happy tummy!

and the best part is it's such huge portions! Definitely bring your friends and family and share everything!!

My second and third experiences at Soyo were suddenly less than stellar. I don't know why we got such bad service and felt like we were still so hungry after spending so much more than we usually do. it just didn't match up to the first time. I'd like to attribute it to just being very hungry the first experience, but the service and quality of food really were fantastic the first time we dined there. I guess it's all relative, but I just felt like it was a so-so situation when i dropped in again. Hopefully that was a fluke.. 2x in a row.. but nonetheless, hopefully.

Yummy Garlic Chicken Wings - crunchy with whole carmalized garlic bulbs - Oh so good- I don't ever like chicken wings - white chicken breast meat is the only chicken part that I enjoy - however, with not much on the menu that didn't scare off the BF - these wings were the way we went and I'm glad we did....

The Kim Chee fried rice was a disappointment- too mushy and not to much flavor - the kim chee taste was there but maybe a dash of salt n pepper would've done the trick. Nice presentation though...

The Dumplings were yummers as well - lightly fried good sized circle shaped dumplings filled with tasty chop chae (clear noodles,finely chopped carrots, onions,and I think spinach)
All the Ban Chan were good especially the sesame seed flavored veggies.

I wish we could pick all the Ban Chan before it comes cause I always feel obligated to eat them or pack it up to go so that nothing is wasted even though I may not like the taste of that particular Ban Chan.

The complimentary Iced Barley tea was a nice touch but after tasting it we opted for water with lemon. Sorry the taste isn't for everybody....

The inside is cute - an old time set up of an old T.V. with flowers and house shoes on top of the T.V. to look as if it were from your grandparents home. There is chalk writing on one wall and chairs hanging up on top of the booth seats.As we were leaving we noticed 2 real old video games as well.

Most of the menu will be odd to most folks but it doesn't hurt to step out of your comfort zone every once in a while cause you never know what you might miss!!!

It made me change my mind about Barley tea. Chilled barley tea in a bowl is what they serve instead of water. Honestly, i didn't like it the very first time i went there, so i asked for water. The second time, i loved it. I love their Barley tea. It's so refreshing and different. 

Let's talk about food. I have been there about 4-5 times now, every time i go there, it's usually late at night. Thank god for they are open till late!!!

 Me and my finance, we tried their pork ribs, beef short ribs lots of different kinds of soups and lot more. Let me tell you, their casseroles are the best. It comes in a big bowl, it's soup-y, steaming hot and plenty for two.

I'd call my self a regular at this place, and I've had good time every time i went in there.
And by the way, service is very good. Very attentive servers!!!!

Great little place that my friend and I found driving around town! The inside is extremely unique and gives the vibe of being a cool,yet fun place to be! I had the spicy tofu soup, which was really good,but not as spicy as I hoped it would be; however, it was still very tasty! The banchan wasn't the best, but everything else besides that made up for it!

I order take out from here from time to time and it is a great place for just that. I like the food but don't like the bar atmosphere so it's a good alternative to take the food out and they do a good job of packing it up nicely.  is pretty money.
I would give 5 stars for them without a doubt!! The chicken wings are excellent!! Everything else was excellent!! Love the little set up in side!
Great authentic korean food try the seafood casserole it is awesome! Will definitely comeback!

Love this restaurant.

First off: the decour- I felt like I was in a mini version of Seoul or Pyongyang from 100 years ago. The booths were inside what was made to look like street stalls from an urban Korean market, very cool!

Second: the food- Holy crap do they give you a lot of food! I ordered this spicy soup and it came with all these little dishes of kimchi, white rice, daikon kimchi, and nori. I was very full.

Lastly: the price- It wasn't half bad. A lot of the options were $10-$15, but considering how much food was offered, it wasn't bad at all.

10/10 I'd go again!
Yum! I always get the gaal bi and cheese don katsu.  I tried the fried rice and that was excellent as well.

Here is great place. Not really big, not very small place. Waiters and waitresses are very kind. Side dishes are delicious too. Price is little bit higher, but food is very tasty. When you order every soup, make sure your spicy level. They have two kinds of soup styles, spicy soup and non spicy soup.

It took quite a while for takeout (despite not many tables being filled) so we played the cool games near the door near the raised seating areas around the place. We liked the dishes we got, but for the price were a bit shocked they came with no sides/banchan or rice of any kind.

If I can give 0 stars, I would. I had an unpleasant time here. 
I work in the restaurant industry and I know what service is. I've been going to this place because I live near here and it was convenient. I have placed togo orders, ate here with friends and family, and brought new customers as well. Whenever new people would ask where to go, I would recommend here for people who lived on this side. However recently I was thoroughly disappointed. 
It was a 1:51 am on Sunday, which also happened to be daylight savings (March 11, 2018). Since I work in the restaurant industry and didn't want to be rude. I called before I went in because even through their closing time is listed as 4am on Saturday night (which is technically Sunday) since they're a local restaurant, they might close sooner. They said they will close in 10 minutes. So I placed an order of kimchi pancakes. Mind you that it was raining that day and I desperately wanted to drink Makkuli. Something Koreans do as a custom when it's raining. It's like drinking a nice cold beer on a sunny day. Anyway, I go in and I see several tables there. I asked if I could buy two makkuli and take it home. They say it's illegal. However, no liquor store was open that carried Makkuli. So I thought maybe I can open the bottles and drink a sip from each and take it home. They answer with a no. Then as my last question, I ask if I can take Makkuli in a different bottle. They say no. I then asked if I can just eat here and drink Makkuli (which was my intention if they weren't closing in ten minutes). They say they're closing in 10 minutes. Also mind you that a single man had come in while I'm waiting and ordered soju to drink at the bar. 
I am a regular. I don't come in every week but for sure once in two months at least and have been for at least 5 years. 
I understand if taking Makkuli is illegal since they might not have the license for it but saying you will close soon and not even have customer service to a regular is impolite especially when I am not asking to be your last customer there. There were at least 5 tables and a single man at the bar. 
Oh and I don't know what kimchi pancake is like at SOYO since it was my first time ordering it here but they gave me one pancake which was burnt on the edges for $10. 
You've lost a customer.

I love this place! I usually get the casserole and add ramen noodles in. There's always enough for leftovers. Try the flat dumplings and the seafood pancake. 

You can also order for pickup. Sit at home with delicious food.

I have some mixed feeling for Soyo as a long time customer for past 8 years, I love the food here and service(most of the time), but sometimes it's hit and miss, finally I decided to leave review due to recent unpleasant experience at Soyo, so a couple month ago, I decided to try something new, so I ordered a oxtail soup noodle (please see my picture under "tip" section", picture on menu looks yummy and looks like a generous portion, but what I got is maybe 2 bites of noodle with barely ANY beef, since it's the first time, I thought maybe they made a mistake so I didn't say anything, couple days ago, I decided to give it a try again, this time comes with even less portion, there's only 2 tiny slice of beef, and I'm not exaggerating, two extremely THIN slice of beef, where in their picture is 4 slice of beef, they even serve the soup to me first without any noodle in there and I had to tell them it's missing noodle, so they brought me a bowl of what seems like 2 or 3 bites of noodle into the soup, and it LOOKS NOTHING like the picture on their menu.  When I talked to the waitress they told me it's normal, they don't give us a lot of noodle and beef, OK, I'm totally fine they do this, but if that's the case, why are they posting inaccurate picture on there tricking people into thinking they are getting a generous portion? I DID NOT appreciate this, this is scam, they either change the photo on menu to match what it really look like, or they give us the right amount of portion JUST LIKE ON THE MENU.  It's simple.

Still freaking good, still missed the goldfish waffle ice creams.
Devoured the jae yuk bokkeum, fried chicken wings, corn cheese, and potato pancakes. I'm totally hooked omg LOL

Yes! Not just a great restaurant, but a great Korean restaurant! 

Immediately greeted with no wait to sit down at around 830 PM! 

I love the Korean pop music playing in the background and the video games while you wait. Drinks were served promptly and I really appreciated that the server repeated our order to make sure he got it right. 

Food came out promptly and was awesome!!! I ordered the jap-chae that was cooked perfectly and everyone said that their food was cooked perfectly as well! I absolutely love all of the sides that come with every meal. Portions are just right and everything tastes fresh!

The yogurt soju was made just right. Lychee was a little too tart for my taste but the alcohol to juice ration was nice. 

The service was excellent and it was a plus that they were really personable and even joked around with us. 

A+! See you next time Soyo!

We're always on the lookout for dining places we haven't tried before, and after our planned destination for dinner failed (too crowded), we decided to try the next door Soyo Korean Barstaurant. The place is very clean and inviting to new patrons, there were small and intimate 'nooks' that we would have preferred to have been seated, but nevertheless, the entire open dining area itself wasn't bad either. Having no idea what their menu was like, we asked our friendly server what she recommends instead of guessing ourselves. We are not new to Korean Food dining, but Soyo offers a different take on traditional Korean BBQ, making things whimsical/modern right down to the way food/drinks was presented (rustic tin canisters in lieu of drinking glasses/tea cup for example). For dinner, our party of three ordered the recommended Chicken Wings In Garlic Sauce, Hot & Spicy Vegetables & Shredded Beef Soup and Bibimbap. The chicken wings, for me, was what stood out the most, the chicken was cooked perfectly: tender and juicy in the inside, crunchy on the outside enhanced by the savory garlic-honey glaze. And oh yeah, grab a lot of napkins for this round folks, because things are going to get real messy (in a good way)! The hot and tender beef soup and colorful bibimbap are more traditional in taste and presentation, and that's also a good thing. We look forward to coming back and sample more dishes from Soyo's menu, we're glad we discovered another good eats place.

You know I always feel bad when my reviews differ so much from my yelp friends. However, this is just my opinion....I don't think that Soyo is all that.  We came here on New Year's after the UFC fight so it was around 10pm? Inside the place looked cool, with the old school tv and what not, the benches are a lil uncomfortable but they provide you with pillows to sit your bum on. 
We were served our doggy dishes for the tea right away, but it took another 20-25 minutes for the server to come back and even take our order. The place wasn't packed and it seemed like everyone there was just "hanging" out. Well when we finally got to order the server told me that they didn't have my oxtail noodle soup....so I ordered this short rib soup.  The food came out probably about 10-15 minutes later which is about average I think. My "soup" was good. The meat was tender for the most part, but there were no noodles. I really wanted something with noodles and the server said this was what replaced the oxtail noodle soup. The rest of my friends enjoyed their meal for the most part. 
Maybe I was just there at the wrong time and didn't order the right thing, but I was not impressed. 
Service really was terrible and I think that ruined the whole Soyo experience for me. I'm a huge sucker for service and when there is no service or lack of service I become this mad woman. When our check came, the server had given us the wrong one. The one she gave us was for an amount WAY cheaper with a discount (about 10-15%) on it, luckily for her I went up to her and said that it was the wrong check. She printed the right check and there was no discount. I wonder how one gets such an awesome discount. In any case for 6 of us, the bill came out to be around 85 something bucks plus tip...which was about right for 5 entrees and 3 soju bombs. Overall, I think I rather drive a lil more and get some Korean BBQ.

LOVE! 
Finally decided to try this place after getting over some intimidation since my only korean dining experience Is AYCE KBBQ lol. 
AMBIANCE- I loved the hip/laid back vibe that this "Barstaurant" presented definitely why I'm coming back, such a cute place, they have fun booths plus anywhere that serves awesome korean food with the korean version of "officially missing you" playing in the background ... Count me in!!! 
SERVICE- My friend and I were total noobs but the servers were more than helpful and friendly, it was just a little awkward at first because once we sat down they gave us a small pitcher of barley tea with these two cup/bowl looking things with no explanation (they serve this over water btw) we weren't sure whether to drink from the bowls or if it's for scraps lol. 
FOOD- so much great options from Galbi, to stews and ramen :) we tried the KOONG NAA MOOL GYUP SAAL - it seems like a popular choice and it was delish! It was pork belly with squid that's in their sweet chili-issh broth, they bring out a portable stove/burner for it to cook all the way and stay warm , definitely adding to the dining experience , plus it was very flavorful! It comes with rice and typical banchan sides. We also tried their flat dumplings which people rave about but it was okay for me, maybe I was expecting it to be out of this world but it'll do :) 
BIG PLUS- SOJU!! The lychee soju was so bomb! Def should try it over the typical yogurt soju ! 

This place is definitely worth trying its great to find a restaurant where you're able to chill and enjoy your food, and it's a great place to hit up with friends. 
MUST TRY .. NOW.

Seemed like the service was going downhill for awhile, but recently they actually seem like they are getting their customer service back in track. The food became a little too sweet but they are still one of the few good korean restaurants to go to. The drinks are offered at reasonable price. Their location and hours of operations are the biggest plus.

Tasty and decent value Korean restaurant! The menu is pretty extensive, so everyone can probably find something they'll like. We enjoyed the free barely tea that they served with large tin bowls, which was very refreshing to drink out of after the hot food. There were about five banchan (side dishes), and one of them was an interesting sweet seaweed that I'd never tried before (good with rice). 

For three people, we ordered:
:: Popular seafood casserole (really like a hot pot) was huge! There was also a lot of good seafood in there like mussels, prawns, octopus, and salmon. We saw some couples who just ordered that to share.  
:: Bulgogi, which was served in in a stone pot with a sweet and salty broth. Definitely needs to be eaten with rice. 
:: Dol sot (hot stone) bi bim bap was good, nothing to complain about, except it would've been nice for it to come with a fried egg.
:: Steamed egg (off menu for $5), which was a mistake as it came out overcooked. It may have been because they don't usually make this dish. They probably forgot about it and left it cooking for too long. It was quite dry and almost green when it was finally served.

This was more than enough food for three people and we had a couple of boxes of leftovers (including rice)! It was still good the next day :)

I know Korean food and this place is NOT very good.  Went here on a friend's recommendation and I was not impressed.  ordered ddeuk bokgi, soon tofu, potato pancake, and seafood pancake.  Soon tofu was probably the best out of the bunch and that was just ok.  maybe I ordered the wrong things.  maybe I expected too much from their food.  if you have a big group and drink this place does support that atmosphere, but judging on food alone there are better Korean places in town.  might give them one more try but this place is not on my go-to list of spots.  positives: most items on the menu are under $10 and they're open late.

I'm a hardcore downtown hipster who rarely deigns to travel west of the 15 or south of Sahara, so when a friend proposed traveling allllll the way out to some strip mall in the hinterlands for some Korean BBQ, I was skeptical: surely there could be nothing of value in suburban stuccoland! But how wrong I was. 

This place felt like stumbling into a weird Burning Man camp on the edge of the playa at 4am -- bright lights, crazy music, tons of people stuffing delicious food into their faces in a sort of post-colonial bacchanal....all going down waaaaaaaay out on the edge of civilization!

Three of us shared a seafood pancake, a bibimbap bowl and some short ribs...plus a lychee cocktail. Everything was great, and there was plenty for everyone for a total tab of $54. Nice! Service was prompt, even around 9pm on a Friday night, when the place was packed.

I'm not a huge fan of Korean food, but the atmo was interesting enough for me to tentatively assert that I might probably come here again.....but only if my wagon breaks down on my way to California and I find myself stranded in the wilderness of SW Vegas.

Soyo's one of my favorite Korean restaurants in town!  When I ask for super spicy (and I'm Korean so I love my super spicy foods), they give it to me super duper spicy!  Well played, Soyo, well played!

My little brother and his wife were visiting and they said they wanted Korean food. So I turned to Yelp to find this place!

We showed up on a Monday night to this cozy and dimly lit place. There was a wait to be seated inside, but they offered up the patio. We were hungry so we chose the patio, which had heaters and plastic flaps. Even with all of that, the January weather had us keeping our warm coats on. 

They sat us down with menus, a plastic bottle of liquid, and three small metal bowls. We were a little unsure of the metal bowls. I kept looking slyly to other tables to see if we were supposed to drink out of them. I had a brief moment of thinking that the entire restaurant would start snickering at how I was drinking out of the bowl that you are really supposed to wash your hands in or something. When the waitress came back, we asked about them and she offered us real glasses if we wanted. So everyone else we saw at other tables had opted for real glasses, which is why we thought the bowls were for something else. But we decided to drink the bottled tea out of the little round metal bowls for an authentic experience.

Part of the reason why we had decided on Korean food was because I had explained what bimbibap was. So of course we ordered bimbibap and it was delicious and it warmed me up on that cold patio. My brother also ordered a dish that was basically chicken wings as I actually do not remember the name for it. The sauce was perfectly saucy with a touch of spice.

Overall, I really enjoyed the chill atmosphere, good service,  and the food. I will definitely explore more of their menu when I go again.

The food is decent, service seems biased when you're not Korean, or a loud good looking teenager/20something.  Whenever I come here I can't stand the crowd.  Not once have I had an order not forgotten.  I've come here with Korean friends or having Koreans near by eating and they would come after, order the same dish, get it before me.  I disliked it man.  I don't wanna bust out the race card but cmon.  Food again is pretty great but service and price make up the other half of the business.

The alcohol they offer isn't any different from anywhere else, and as for the price, I'm thinking every year the value drops for me.  I would come here if I'm craving Korean and not wanting to go any further to eat somewhere else.  It's nice to have a restaurant here that isn't KBBQ but again I wouldn't choose to come here whenever I feel hungry or in the neighborhood.  The portions, the saltiness, is all off :P  Yeah it's dope they have a lil arcade cabinet thingy but that's probably the best part and not the food or service.

You'll find the majority of the patrons here are young, and korean or like weaboo types.  Find another spot more Mom and Pop that would cater more to service and better recipes for a better price.

I have had this spot bookmarked for awhile. I have been here twice in four nights for dinner. Both times were enjoyable and I have found my new favorite restaurant, just in time to celebrate the PyeongChang Winter Olympics!

On Saturday night, I met my newlywed friends for dinner at 6pm. I took Yelpers' advice and made reservations, which I was glad we did. We were able to snag a booth and it started to get busy after we got seated. Immediately, as we sat down, we were given ice cold barley tea, which was refreshing. We ordered 1/2 and 1/2 order of fried chicken wings, 3 Yang Nyum (Korean-style wings with a zesty sauce) and 3 Ma Nuel (with garlic-flavored sauce),  Bi Bim Baap, soups, Sul Lung Tang (milky soup with ox tail, beef slices, and noodles), and Beef Soon Doo Boo Jji Gae (tofu soups, asked for no spice) and Nap Jaak Man Doo (handmade flat dumplings with ground beef & pork, clear noodles and vegetables). Soon after ordering, we received ban chan: kim chee, potato salad, radish kim chee, and seasoned broccoli. Pretty standard fare, nothing special. The favorites were the chicken wings. They were so good, we ordered another set of wings. Paul, who ordered the ox tail soup, complained that his soup was plain with zero ox tail. This was the only complaint of our meal. I was very happy with my tofu soup. While it wasn't the best I've had, it was tasty, all hot and bubbling, with a raw egg dropped in the boiling soup. Ana her bi bim baap was good, but nothing spectacular. The service was a bit inattentive and slow at times, but they did come and refill the ban chan and barley tea when asked. Overall, we did have a good time.

Last night, I took my parents for our Mardi Gras dinner. Again, I made reservations. This is the way to go here to ensure you get one of the 5 booths. My dad got the korean bbq, LA Kal Bi, beef short ribs. I got the 1/2 1/2 of the chicken wings and the Man Doo dumplings again. My mom wanted soup because she wasn't feeling well, a shredded beef soup. This time around, everyone loved their entrees. The ban chan was kim chee, radish kim chee, beans, seaweed, and cellophane noodles. My dad loved the radishes that accompanied the chicken wings. The vinegary taste really complemented the flavors of the wings. My mom said her soup really "hit the spot" and made her feel better. Again, the service was spotty and you had to call someone over if you needed something, instead of them coming over the check on you. This is why I am giving 4 stars, instead of 5. 

I look forward to my next visit to this fine, Korean, establishment in my area. I am glad I don't have to go all the way to Spring Mountain for great Korean food.

I had one of the best meals at Soyo most recently. Keep that chef cooking in the back because it's amazing!

I had boo dae chigae (military soup) and it was by far one of the best I've had. 

The ttuk pokki (spicy rice cakes) were also on point with the sauce being thick and not watery like some places. 

The chaewook bokkum (spicy pork) was legit with tender meat and amazing, robust flavored. 

Kimchi Jun (kimchi pancake) was super crispy through out--exactly the best way to eat it.
If they keep this up, it'll be hard to keep me away from being a weekly regular.

We usually come here during the late evening hours. The food is usually decent but tonight was terrible. We ordered LA Galbi & we basically got bones with fat - literally no meat! $16 for bones?! Ridiculous! Not satisfied AT all & extremely disappointed.

First time I've ever been to a restaurant where I was served by 4 different waitresses within 2 minutes...

The place is basically an outdoor Korean bar ( pojangmacha [like what you see in Korean dramas where the protagonist often goes to get drunk when they are sad]) made into an indoor shop (thank god...or we'd die from LV heat).

Felt out of place since the crowd when I came were younger kids or novelty seekers.  Food tasted pretty good, however it was soon evident that it was overpowered with MSG... Service was great (probably because I had 4 waitresses for my 1 table...)

Overall... it's just okay. I rounded up to 4 stars.

ordered the budae jjigae and it was goood, feeds at least two people. ate it before a hike in re rock canyon, maybe not the best idea, better for a cold night or right after some heavy drinkin.

service was great. squid qppetizer was okay, kinda too sweet. the lady thought I was filipino so she recommended the squid dish ahaha.

Ambiance is great! That's actually what keeps me coming back for my takeout. But for authentic Korean food, not exactly authentic. Everything I've tried has been pretty mediocre. Honestly Greenland Supermarket food court is better than this place! Service is spot on though!!

Great environment for college kids. The appetizers are great. The soju is really tasty, I recommend the grapefruit flavor. Our server was constantly checking on us as well which was nice. You have the option of outside or inside seating.

This restaurant is great for groups! Outdoor seating option, heated fans, great social environment to sit and enjoy a meal with friends. 

The Koreans in our group approved of the authentic menu options available here. They giggled at the sight of the barley tea served in the cool metal cups. We were told that they, themselves had never encountered that before. I loved it! Free barley tea. 

We had a vegetarian in our group and she had no trouble finding things on the menu to serve her needs. She had the bibimbap. I had the tofu soup that contained the traditional Korean fermented soybean paste. The soup base was different than Japanese miso. The Korean version is much more pungent and requires a bit of an adventurous spirit to try, at least that's what my Korean friend sitting next to me said. 

There were orders of kalbi, mackerel, pork belly. Everyone at the table ordered a diverse selection of dishes and there were  many murmurs of approval during our meal.

Hidden in a strip mall, this Korean restaurant exceeded expectations.  We've been there a few times now and it's always consistently good.  The Dolsat Bibimbap and BBQ Kalbi are both really good. It's definitely better than any of the Korean restaurants we've been to back home in San Francisco!

My boyfriend and I are regulars here. We love it so much that we come at least once a week or every other week for their bulgogi stone pot. We love the broth so we always ask for extra broth and a fried egg on top. Their seafood udon and pork belly salad are also favorites as well but the stone pot is a must everytime

I would give this place like a 3.5, but yelp doesn't give me that option.  Ok, after the good reviews on yelp I definitely wanted to check this place out.  I love the interior design, and its location.  Once we entered, the people greeted us and sat us quickly.  (Something I definitely love, the quicker I get to eat....the better.)  The server gave us 2 bowls and iced tea I suppose?  I didn't know what to do with it, so I just poured it into the bowl and drank it.  My mother and I just looked at each other and then thought we used this to wash our hands.  (LOL, but that didn't make any sense since it had ice)  

After looking at the menu, I didn't know what to order.  I guess I'm a visual eater than a reader.  I wish they had specialties recommended or something, cause I was totally lost!

I ordered:

Kimchi Fried Rice - It was ok.  I think I like ichiza's better because it actually comes with kimchi.  I think the rice was little too sticky, and a little too spicy.  The egg was refreshing though, but overall I thought it was OK.

Corn with Mozerella Cheese - It was good.  I thought the sauce that was mixed with the cheese while being served on a hot pot was pretty genius.  I did wish the serving was little bigger since I was paying like $5.00 for it.  

Garlic Squid - This dish was very good, although I got more garlic than I did squid.  I kind of felt jipped a little, and with that price I was expecting a little more than just garlic.

Green Mussel Soup - It was pretty good.  The portions were good, and the flavor of the soup was ok.  It was nothing to brag about.  They did add a lot of mussels and what not.  

I thought this place was an OK spot.  The thought of Korean tapas is genius, but they were pretty greedy with their portions. (Maybe something they could improve?)  Even the veggies they serve as side items were small.  It looked like someone took one scoop and just served it.  I might return cause the service was good, but I don't know about the prices.  I paid almost $40 just for those dishes alone.  I felt like I could've gotten more out of it than I should.

Whenever I'm in town, Soyo is a great choice for some "comfort" food.

Great environment and comfy. Music selection is fitting according to my taste, which is Korean music. 

The food is good. Stuff I've had from my visits is their army stew (budajigae), korean fried chicken,  cold noodles, Kimchi fried rice, spicy rice cake and tofu soup. Probably other food which I've forgotten. 

For a" barstaurant" restaurant/ bar, their Korean food is great. 

Everything is tasty and filling. You need go try it out. 

I wish there is one in California.
Delicious food, great fried rice in a stone pot. great place. Music is slightly loud, but bearable.

Solid choice for Korean food in a city with very few good Korean options. The seafood tofu soup (soondubu) is awesome at $9 and comes with banchan and a bowl of rice. My mom ordered the hot stone bibimbap and gave it a thumbs up. We also ordered the deep fried rice cakes on skewers which were CRISPY AND DELICIOUS. Highly recommend for the $2 or so.

Service was super fast and we came at an off hour so no wait. Parking is plentiful.

Really really good place. Reminds me of my childhood!  I got the bool dak which is a fish stick soup with radish and pineapple soju. Great combination with friends! My friend got the japchae,  a glass noodle dish paired with his bool dak, which is chicken with cheese. All in all the staff was attentive to our needs, even when it's late at night (we came at 2pm and it was still packed!). Highly recommended! GFRIEND FOREVER
My friend took me here. Loved the atmosphere and the inside was cozy and inviting. We ordered the kal bi, soup, and seafood pancake. Delicious food. Definitely will come back here.

Great Korean food away from Spring Mnt. Road, in the SW valley.
The staff is amazing, friendly, fast and patient, as we usually sit around and talk too long before we ever look at the menu.

The food is great, not as good as my wife's halmoni, but much much better than other places we have ate at.

The Bibimbap came in a sizzling hot pot, and the rice on the bottom had the crispy goodness. The portion size was enough for 2, and what we didn't finish became breakfast the next morning.
I had the Bibim Naeng Myeon... Great tasting spicy cold noodles, with enough kochujang to give it a great kick!
The Kimchi Bokeumbap was outstanding, enough for 3 to share.
Highly recommend

DELICIOUS FOOD!!!

All 7 of us fit in the booth and ordered some tasty dishes. We had a peach soju cocktail (yum!), casserole, the number 2 on the menu (don't know how to spell it), these ribs, and other noodle dishes. Excellent prices and we were so full when we were done. 

They had the barley tea in pitchers. Great service. We're fans and coming back. About 10 mi. from the strip, I think..?

I feel like Soyo is very unassuming from its barstaurant feel. There's soju caps hanging here and there as decor and string lights from booth to booth. It's a very relaxed and fun environment.

I came here with a few friends in the late evening (~10:30-11pm) and got a few dishes to share. Everything we got was amazing. It was flavorful without being over seasoned/over-salted. We got the bossam, bulgogi in soup, korean fried chicken, korean pancake, and rice cakes w/ ramen. My favorite has to be the bossam. It's the best bossam I've had in Las Vegas so far, and I've been having dreams of it for at least the past 3 days. The ssamjang, garlic, kimchi, and mini shrimps really complimented the pork well without overpowering the pork. It was a match-made in heaven, and I feel like I'm fiending to get back here to eat it. 

The Korean pancake was crisp on the edges and soft on the inside. It was everything that you could ask for in a toasty pancake, and portion sizing was so generous. It's something you definitely have to share with a few people.

The fried chicken was great in my opinion, but then again, I loved the sauce. I just couldn't get enough of it. The chicken is smothered in the sauce, so if you don't like a super saucy wing, then you might not have a good time with this one. If you're like me and like sauce though, then you'll probably die happy after these wings. You can taste some subtle garlic flavor underneath its tangy, sweet crunch. 

The rice cakes were cooked to perfection. It wasn't overcooked internally and it was chewy without being sticky. The sauce wasn't too sweet which was great. I've had some overly sweet ddeokbokki sauce and it just completely ruined the dish, but not this one. There's a pack of ramen cooked right into it with some carrot & cabbage shreds. Oh so satisfying and delicious!

On the slight downside, the service was kind of slow. There were probably 5 tables there and about 3 employees working. Even then, the food came out pretty slow and it took a while for the waiters to come by to refill waters/etc. 

Overall, the food is great to a point that I'm using every excuse I can to get my friends to come back with me. With so many great options and generous dishes, you definitely should come with a few people and share. That way, you can get a little of everything!
I enjoying coming here for their tofu soup and fried pork belly. Wish I could give more stars but they seem to lack service here in majority all the times that I come.

Very authentic Korean food, and very authentic friendly service! I've been to Soyo Barstaurant three times so far, and the food and service has been consistent. 

Korean food cuisine is one of my top favorites that I crave, that I've learned to make a few dishes at home (bibimbap, kimchi jjigae & bibimgooksu) But the times I don't want to cook, I drive up the block and over to Soyo. They have DELICIOUS lychee soju that I can't get at home and yummy little sides of banchan (with refills at request).

FOOD
Kimchi jjigae - Spicy and filled with lots of kimchi, the amount of anchovy, kimchi, garlic & gochujang hot pepper paste is perfect. It goes amazingly well with the complimentary barley tea and the portion size along with the banchan and rice is super filing. 

Kalbi soup - Nonspicy, but comes with a good amount of beef and vegetables. The broth is a little on the bland side, but adding in extra dippings and hot sauce really makes the broth's flavor enhanced. It tastes fresh too, but I think the Kimchi jjigae is more to my liking.

Lychee soju - Perfect perfect perfect amounts of soju, soda & lychee yogurt! The size and presentation of the soju in a glass bottle is charming and enough to make 2-4 people satisfied. Not pass out drunk, but happy =) 

Maa Neul (Tongdak) garlic-chili marinated Chicken Wings - MUST GET MUST GET! After drinking at Oyshi and then at Soyo, we very much enjoyed this greasy, crispy, garlic chili marinated chicken wings. They have lots of meat on them and the serving is I believe 6-8 pieces. 

Duk bokki - Large portion of rice cakes, spicier than I expected it to be, so we brought it home and ate it with more rice the next day. Had a soft boiled egg on top and fishcakes. The soft boiled egg was the piece de resistance. Next time I think I'll order an extra boiled egg. Really good!

Bi Bim Gook Soo - Cold noodles in spicy sauce with thinly sliced cucumbers, other veggies and I think it had a soft-boiled egg. Anyway, one of my favorite dishes and something about cold noodle dishes are just refreshing. Must try. And the price is satisfying for the portion.

Overall, my meal was great The service was attentive and they made sure the tables were clean and void of any empty dishes. They refilled a couple banchan that I requested and promptly. I know we spent over the amount that makes you eligible to spin their "Free Stuff" wheel, but we forgot to ask about that. Maybe next time! And next time will definitely be soon.

Kim chee perfection! I love the little opening dishes of turnip, black beans, bean sprouts, gochujang and cabbage. Its spiced to my palates perfection. This spice and flavor is what I compare other preparations by.

The bibimbap tastes healthy and the rice is crisped beautifully in the stone hot pot. It keeps its temperature well. The bulgogi bbq style are thin slices of sweet meat with carrots, white and green onions.

Lots of delectable CHEESE covered items. 

In and outdoor seating. Iced brewed tea served with ice in a jug. Lots of parking. Looks like it can get pumping in the later evening with all their alcohol drinks.

Let me start by saying that I'm not a fan of Korean food.  My girlfriend likes this place and I like to see her happy, so we go often.  This is her favorite Korean restaurant in Vegas, where we live.  There is plenty of parking.  The atmosphere is pretty cool.  We always sit in a booth.  Each booth has walls that go all the way up creating privacy and a sense if intimacy.  The servers are friendly, helpful, and clean.  Korean pop music and a little Korean rap provide additional cultural ambiance.  Popcorn tea is served before you order.  Its a little weird, but definitely reminds me of popcorn.  Various side dishes come out with every meal.  A lot of pickled stuff.  The only one I can name is kimchi.  My girlfriend loves the hot kimchi soup.  I'm starting to like it too.  I like to pour it over rice.  By the way, they never seem to give me enough rice.  My favorite entree here is the galbi.  Probably because it is closest to stuff I normally eat.  It is BBQ ribs sliced very thin and served on grilled vegetables on a hot skillet.  The bulgogi is also pretty good.  Thin sliced meat served in a soup.  We ordered the fried calamari once.  It was pretty good, but had a lot of garlic.  Once we tried Korean style sushi.  It was okay.  Another time we tried a seafood soup.  It sounded so good.  It had all sorts of seafood.  However, the meat was too hard to get to.  It was really messy so I gave up.  I was really disappointed.  The plates, bowls, and eating utensils are all very stylish.  I really enjoy experiencing other cultures and love trying their foods.  I'm beginning to like Korean food more and even developing a taste for kimchi.  If you like Korean food then I highly recommend this place.

I have been here for many times when i need some spicy food and all the times i got the best service and good test of Korean food but tonight i'm honestly to say that they are the worth ever server that i found .... For next time i hope they will change their service

Food was amazing tried the short ribs and pork belly. We also ordered two flavors of soju lychee and peach both were delicious. Service was a little slow we got sat right away then no one took our order for a while.

Me and girlfriend ate here a few month back and remember we had a great experience. The place was clean, not too noisy, great theme, slightly dim and good customer service. It's not your typical Korean spot at your local chinatown.

New favorite restaurant!  Menu selection was great with a ton of variety.  Service was excellent for us as well.  Living in the southwest of Las Vegas I love that this place is close to me.  Dining for two or even in a big group this place is a most go!

I will NEVER go back to Soyo.  The food actually was not that bad.  However the service was deplorable.  They just don't seem to care.

We even had Korean speaking people at our table and their lunch was ruined because of the service.

What I love about Soyo is the ambience it creates for itself.  When you walk in, the restaurant is dimly lit with lights strung all around the room, k-pop music plays in the background, and the tables are large and spaced out far enough to allow parties to be loud and comfortable.  

The food here is great!  Korean food is communal.  The dishes at Soyo are big enough for large parties and everything tastes great. Some of my favorites include:

Yang nyum chicken aka KFC!  Mmm it really is finger lickin' good.  The chicken is sweet, a little spicy, garlicky, and double fried to perfection!  

Budae jjigae: the army base stew is pretty much ramen on steroids.  A big pot of spicy ramen with spam, vienna sausage, the chewy rice cake stick, vegetables.  It's perfect during the cold, winter nights and it's large enough to share with 6-8 people.  You can also ask for extra noodles!

Everything else that I've tried here is good!  I love that the portions are big enough to share so that you can try all Soyo has to offer.  They offer flavored soju!  Very good and verrry addicting!  Service can be a little slow, but I don't notice it as much because they give you a jug of water and barley tea that you can refill yourself.  

Soyo creates a comfortable atmosphere where it makes you feel like you're enjoying a meal at home with friends.  What's even better is that you don't have to do any of the cooking!

LOVED it! It was a great atmosphere, super friendly staff that helped with the wide variety of items on the menu. Presentation was good, food was served quickly even though the place was packed and we had to wait when we arrived.  Honestly, the spicy bbq pork ribs were the best I've ever had. I'd definitely go back!

I could eat at SoYo weekly.  Cute place and fun atmosphere.  The staff is always attentive and friendly.  It's a bonus they are open late.  This is the rice omelet, really tasty.  

I've also tried and really enjoy the Bi Bim Baap

Located off of Rainbow and 215, Soyo always leaves me feeling satisfied with my meal. 

Ambience 5/5 -- the atmosphere of the place is extremely comforting. The overall interior design of the place as well as the atmosphere makes this a good place for my friends and I to casually go. I love the lights :) after 11pm the music gets a little louder and seems to be more of a bar than a restaurant which is cool too. 

Food 5/5 -- I am a fan of Korean cuisine and have tried many of the dishes as Soyo. I love them all! They are all well-cooked and delicious. My favorite dish is the L.A. gaalbi.
